Ottawa, November 9, 1937.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of November 1, you may purchase for use at the Little Red River Indian Day School, one kettle, two brooms, and one cheap mirror.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

R.S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.

Sweedsmuir, Sask.

Sweedsmuir, Sask.

Dear Sir:

The well at Little Red River School has been dry most of the winter. This well has never been satisfactory and has not enough water to keep the school and Teacher's residence supplied.

The Teacher has requested that a new well be dug which I believe is the only solution. However I feel that we can not get a good well without going down at least 80 feet; the cost would be around $250.00. This school is located where it is very uncertain of a well which would supply a good flow of water.

Ottawa,
June 17, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 13th instant, requesting authority to dig a new well at the Little Red River Indian Day School.

In your letter of January 30, 1939, you wrote in part as follows, with reference to the Little Red River School:

"This school now has a well that should do them for a number of years; whereas if the extra nine feet were not completed it may have been necessary to dig a new well within a very few years owing to the small supply of water that would have been available."

In view of the difficulty in securing water at this point, the Department does not feel disposed to authorize the digging of a new well, unless you can give a definite assurance that a plentiful supply of water can be secured. From the information quoted above from your own communication it would appear that in 1939 you were under the impression that the well dug at that time would last for several years.

Yours truly,

Mr. R.S. Davis,
Indian Agent,

I wish to inform you that I have a letter from Agent Jones, Carlton Agency, with respect to the barn accommodation at the Little Red River School.

Mr. Jones informs me that Mr. Risedorf, husband of the present teacher there, has around 15 head of goats and three horses. The old barn which is 12 x 16 is too small and he suggests that an addition 14 x 16 be added. If approved he will endeavour to obtain the price of the material required for such an addition.

Also, Mr. Risedorf believes there are about 20 acres of land belonging to the school and he would like to get permission to work this land for his own use. I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Christianson which reads as follows:

"I wish to inform you that I have a letter from Agent Jones, Carlton Agency, with respect to the barn accommodation at the Little Red River School.

"Mr. Jones informs me that Mr. Risedorf, husband of the present teacher there, has around 15 head of goats and three horses. The old barn which is 12 x 16 is too small and he suggests that an addition 14 x 16 be added. If approved he will endeavour to obtain the price of the material required for such an addition.

"Also, Mr. Risedorf believes there are about 20 acres of land belonging to the school and he would like to get permission to work this land for his own use. As I have said in another letter, I do not know the teacher and her husband on Little Red River Reserve and was never informed of their names. Also I have not the slightest idea to what land he is referring. However, I am submitting this to our Branch for their consideration."

From the above the Department presumes that the teacher's husband is residing on the reserve. This is the first intimation that we have had of this action on his part. It is difficult to understand why the teacher's husband should assume that he can come in on the reserve with a considerable quantity of livestock and in addition try to obtain twenty acres of land to work for his own use. Such action is bound to receive unfavourable criticism from the Indians and as a consequence will militate against any work that the teacher is doing."
It is not our intention to spend any money in fixing the barn at the Little Red River School. As a matter of fact we do not seem to have any information on our file about this barn. Mr. Riedorf should remove his goats and horses from the reserve and should be definitely informed that the Department has no intention of placing twenty acres at his disposal.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I have received a letter today from Mr. Jones, Indian Agent, Carlton Agency, with respect to the water situation on the Little Red River Reserve.

In the first case I might say this is the first time I was aware of the fact that the teacher on that reserve was Mrs. Risedorf. As usual, in the last two years we have never been informed as to the names of the teachers engaged for the various Indian Day Schools in this province.

Now referring back to the water situation I understand that an Indian has been hired to haul water there but the Agent informs me this has not proven satisfactory. Mr. Risedorf, the husband of the teacher, is of the opinion that he can get a supply of water at a depth of 24 ft. and he is going to put down a test hole. If he finds water then with your recommendation we should sanction a well there. The Agent estimates that it will take about 500 ft. of lumber and this will cost around $25.00 as well as 15 lbs. of 4" spike nails at .09¢ a lb. Also Mr. Risedorf is prepared to dig the well at $1.00 per ft. We will require therefore around $50.00 in total.

I would request if funds are available this expenditure be approved providing that Mr. Risedorf succeeds in finding a location with a good supply of water through preliminary tests.

March 31, 1947
Dear Sir,

We cannot continue teaching in this school unless some repair work is done.

We have already had a heavy fall of snow.

We have completed forms but this seems to be pretty slow.

Yours Truly,

H.A. Smith
TEACHER
AIR MAIL

Ottawa, October 31, 1947.

Mr. E.S. Jones, Indian Agent,
Leask, Saskatchewan.

The following letter has just been received from Mr. H.A. Smith, teacher of the Little Red River Indian Day School.

"We cannot continue teaching in this school unless some repair work is done. We have already had a heavy fall of snow. We have completed forms but this seems to be pretty slow."

The Department approves you making emergency repairs in order to make the school as comfortable as possible for this teacher.

You might also let me have a report regarding conditions at this school.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PP/MGD
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa.

Reference is made to letter 107-4-5 (W.T.l) of October 31, 1947, re: a letter forwarded to the Department by Mr. H. A. Smith, teacher of the Little Red River Indian Day School. Matters pertaining to this school were fully discussed with Mr. Smith some time ago. He eventually prepared a requisition for supplies which will be in the hands of the Department by this time.

I visited the school on November 5th which was a day previous to receiving your letter. Mr. Smith did not mention having written the Department.

Due to having been vacant for a year, this school is not in particularly good repair. Two small pieces of plaster have fallen off the wall and the whole of the plaster has loosened sufficiently to require replacement next summer, but some other type of finish would be recommended, this matter was discussed with Mr. Smith. The windows of the classroom open from the bottom, Mr. Smith complained that this was not correct and requested immediate steps be taken to correct this error in construction. I explained it would be impossible to obtain the services of a carpenter to go that distance into the country at this time of year to make these changes.

Mr. Smith also requested a ventilator be placed in the floor immediately under the heater. I discussed the latter with a heating expert in Prince Albert who ruled the suggestion was not practical.
Glass has been on order for replacement for some time, this should soon be available.

A range for the teacher's residence which was authorized has been purchased and freighted to the Reserve.

At the present time I am not prepared to report favourably on Mr. Smith's suitability for his present position.

E. S. Jones,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, September 26, 1929.

Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Ven. Archdeacon Paul, Prince Albert, nominating the services of Mr. Joseph Chamberlain as teacher of the proposed new Indian day school at Little Island Lake on the Ministikwan reserve, No. 161. He states that Mr. Chamberlain has had previous teaching experience. The Department is approving of his appointment, with salary at the rate of $60 per teaching month, this being the amount that can be allowed for a teacher having the qualifications which he possesses. He is to begin duties when the new school building is ready.

Archdeacon Paul states that he recently visited this place and that the Indians are going to start on the work of getting out logs and erecting the building at once. In this connection I would refer you to official letter of April 23rd, last, in which you were informed that the Department would grant the finishing lumber, hardware, etc. I shall be pleased if you will furnish a report on the progress that is being made in the erection of the building and when the work will be completed. You should also report as to what classroom supplies are required.

Relative to the desks, it is thought that tables and benches could be made locally which would be satisfactory until such time as it is ascertained the success which will be made in the work and the attendance of the Indian children.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Long Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Ottawa, March 25th, 1937.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 15th instant, in which you state that Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, teacher of the Ministikwan Indian Day School, has been advised to give up duties owing to illness. Present regulations will only permit our allowing Mr. Chamberlain leave with pay for one month. I would, therefore, appreciate if you would advise me, as soon as possible, the exact date on which he was obliged to close the school.

At the same time, you should forward a medical certificate stating the date just mentioned and, also, the approximate date on which it is expected he will be able to resume duties.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dr. J. T. Hill,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.
April 12, 1937.

MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury.

Re School No. 615.

The Department is advised that Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, teacher of the Ministikwan Indian Day School, has been advised to give up duties owing to illness. No information has reached the Department regarding the length of time he will be absent and, in view of this, his name should be omitted from the April paylist.
April 15, 1937.

MEMORANDUM:

Representative of the Treasury,

With reference to my memorandum of the 12th instant, the Indian Agent has advised the Department that Mr. Joseph Chamberlain, teacher of the Ministikwan Indian Day School, was able to resume duties after the Easter holidays and, in view of this, his name should appear on the April paylist, as follows:-

Ottawa, January 21, 1930.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 7th instant, with reference to engaging the services of a driver, during the winter months, to transport the children to and from the Ministikwan Indian Day School. In this connection it is noted you recommend that an allowance of $20 per month be made to O-see-mee-mas, who has been performing this service since the school was started in November, last, without any question of remuneration. It is further noted that 9 of the pupils live a distance of from one to five miles from the school.

The Department will approve of the payment at the rate of $20 per month for the transporting of these children each school day to and from school. Payment at this rate will be allowed from the first of January, upon receipt of certified vouchers, in duplicate, from time to time, from you, covering the amount due. If O-see-mee-mas continues to perform this duty, it is expected he will see that all who are of school age and in good health attend regularly. The Department is pleased to note, from the quarterly return received showing the attendance for the December quarter, last, that there was an enrolment of 13 pupils, with an average attendance of slightly over 11.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Lang Turner, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Onion Lake, Sask.

Indian Affairs Branch - Ottawa.

I submit the following report on the affairs of this Agency for the quarter ended September 30, 1946.

EDUCATION

I visited the Onion Lake R.C. Indian Residential School on September 6 and 14, and the Blue Quills School on September 9th. The Frog Lake, Long Lake, Big Island Lake and Onion Lake, Indian Day Schools were visited on the 9th, 10th, 12th and 16th, respectively. It was decided to re-open the Ministikwan Indian Day School and repairs to School and Teacher's house have been carried out. A new well was dug and the school barn repaired also. We are now awaiting the arrival of a teacher.

Donald H. Cameron,

3 Sept: 47.

J.P.B. Ostrander Esq:
Inspector of Indian Agencies
Regina, Sask.

With reference to the attached Requisition, Mr J.P. Mullan, teacher at Ministikiwin Indian Day School, has requested that repairs to his living quarters be made.

The house is a log building and he states that it was very cold last winter, despite all efforts to chink etc.

I visited Mr Mullan's house and school about three weeks ago for the first time, but waited until it was possible to speak to him on his return from vacation on 28 August.

There is only one latrine at this school, a log affair, which is used by the boys, and should be moved to a new site. It appears that the girls have been using the one at the school house. This is not right and I have provision for two new ones in the Requisition.

I recommend that authority be given to carry out this work. If it is not possible to have all the repairs at the house carried out this year, at least some should be done.

(H.S. Packman)
A/Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I am enclosing copy of a letter covering requisitions submitted by Mr. Packman, Clerk-in-Charge of the Onion Lake Agency, requesting permission for $245.19 worth of repair work to be done on the Ministikwan Indian Day School.

There was no provision made for this expenditure in the Onion Lake Estimates for this year but $300.00 was requested for Long Lake Indian Day School. Mr. Packman informs me that not over $65.00 of this $300.00 will be spent on Long Lake; therefore if he could have permission to proceed with his proposal it would mean an expenditure of $27.00 in excess of the Estimates for school repairs. If this cannot be approved could Mr. Packman be given authority to proceed with the work not to exceed the unused portion of his Estimates of $215.00. I would recommend that Mr. Packman be given authority to carry out these repairs and on account of shipping difficulties and the supply of material it would be more economical if you were given permission to make local purchases from approved sources.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, September 24th, 1947.

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Saskatchewan.

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $242.19 for material and labour in repairing the Ministikiwin Day School. Purchase of materials may be made locally from approved sources.

Bernard F. Neary
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

PERSONAL and CONFIDENTIAL

Mr. J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Regina, Sask.

Ministikwan Indian Day School.

Reference your letter of June 17 and feel that Mrs. Van Norman should be appointed at the Loon Lake School and Miss Krafft at the Ministikwan School.

As we can probably anticipate complaints concerning the school at Ministikwan, I would like your advice as to what we should do to put it in better condition by September first. I note our files indicate that a teacherage is the main requirement at Ministikwan. Please find attached a self-explanatory letter which I have sent to Mr. Davis concerning a teacherage we ordered for the Split Lake School. This was a prefabricated building purchased from North American Buildings, Limited, at a price of $2,037. I believe it should be quite satisfactory for Ministikwan.

On the other hand you might wish to recommend the erection of a school based on plan 888. If so, we could arrange to include an amount in our supplementary estimates due in September, 1949.

I know that you will realize the necessity of making conditions at Ministikwan as comfortable for Miss Krafft as possible - otherwise we can anticipate some difficulty with Bishop Martin. I am writing to Miss Krafft today advising her of her appointment at Ministikwan.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Attention of Colonel Neary

I am in receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, File 637-1 (E), with which was enclosed copy of a personal and confidential letter to me dated July 11th, 1949, file 615-5 (E), regarding the Ministikwan Indian Day School.

With respect to the condition of the buildings at that point, I wrote Mr. Davis on June 6th, 1949, asking him to report as to what was needed to put the building in shape, and I have not had a reply. I have again brought this to his attention. However, I am definitely in favour of the erection of a combined school and teacherage on the Ministikwan Reserve, based on Plan #828, as this will eventually have to take place and it will be much more advisable than spending the amount of money which will probably be necessary to put the present building in fair shape.

If this meets with your approval I would ask that you kindly include this amount in the Supplementary Estimates due in September, 1949, in the hope that it can be rushed through and completed for opening not later than the 1st of January, 1950.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Re: Repairs, Ministikwan Indian Day School No.615

In the 1949-50 Estimates the amount of $100.00 was allowed for the repairing of the above school. We now find that this amount will be insufficient to complete the necessary work. Would you, through your office, request Ottawa for additional monies in this respect, as well as authority to expend the estimated $100.00. This $100.00 will cover the minor repairs and banking but it is also necessary that a pump be installed which would amount to $45.00. There are no ceilings in either the school or the living quarters. This is necessary in order to make the buildings more comfortable. It would take approximately $60.00 to cover it with Kraft paper and a small amount of lumber. There are also locks required and some windows and window panes which amounts to approximately $7.00. A hinged flag pole, $6.00, and other incidentals such as paint, varnish, screws for desks, amounting to approximately $35.00.

I have tried to keep the cost as low as possible in this old school and teacherage as it is not worth spending much money on, yet it is necessary to make the place habitable until a proper school and teacherage is built. I am forwarding to Ottawa school requirements necessary for the operation of this school.

Would ask your assistance in getting permission to spend the above amounts.

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan.

With reference to your letter of November 24th, file 615-5 (El) and the attached Vouchers 759 and 760.

We were trying for some considerable time to get a teacher for this school and it looked for a while as if we would be unable to get anyone to teach this school. I did not care to make any expenditures on this school until we were sure of procuring a teacher. Eventually we were able to get the services of the present teacher and it was urgent that we get the school opened as quickly as possible before the winter set in. This teacher was prepared to move into the buildings and start school as soon as we had the supplies.

There was also a strong demand from the Indians to get this school started. To show you the response to this demand the attendance is larger than this school can accommodate. While the cost of these supplies was higher than I have authority to spend, yet the need was urgent, and I took it upon myself to get this school going as soon as possible.

When checking Voucher 759 over we find that it should total $107.81, instead of 109.97 as we had omitted to take off the Education Tax which we do not have to pay.

Re: the three brooms in paragraph 2 of your letter, This is a very old building and the very heavy stable broom is used for scrubbing the floor. The push broom, which is quite expensive, is used for daily sweeping on the part of the floor which is painted, and the third house broom is used for daily sweeping on the parts of the floor which are too rough for the hair push broom which would soon wear out if used on same. Only by using these three brooms can this building be kept clean.
With reference to the third paragraph of your letter, our Voucher No.760 in the amount of $7.50 for delivery of supplies to the school.

It is approximately 35 miles from Pierceland to the school over almost impassible roads; a round trip of 70 miles. Had we used a freighting firm to deliver these supplies the cost would certainly have been a great deal more.

By taking the short cut and more or less disregarding the rules and regulations we were able to have the school in operation by November 1st, 1949. The prices are on a parity with other supplies that we purchased for other schools where we had authority to make local purchase.

Hope this expenditure has been explained satisfactorily and would ask your special consideration re: the payment of this account.

(J.A. Davis)
Superintendent,
Meadow Lake Indian Agency.

Ottawa, February 11, 1909.

The Deputy Supt. General,-

In a memorandum prepared by me on November 16, 1907, on the question of Indian education I referred to the report of Mr. Inspector Chisholm, who drew attention to the school on the Mistawasis reserve in charge of the Rev. Mr. Bryden, and to the note of the Commissioner, who said that, if we had day schools like this, boarding schools might be dispensed with.

A subsequent report received from Mr. Chisholm shows that Mr. Bryden is still pursuing his successful course as teacher and missionary on the reserve, and it appears to me that the Department should recognize his exceptional ability as shown in the conduct of the day school under his charge.

The present salary attached to this school is $300, the amount set apart for all the schools in the Northwest, and I think it is time that some distinction should be made between the successful and the unsuccessful teacher. Mr. Bryden's school is almost the only one that has called for special commendation from our Inspectors, and he receives no more for his good work than numbers of teachers who are admittedly failures and totally unfitted for
for the work in which they are engaged. If an exception could be made in his favour, it would be the means of stimulating the efforts of some of the other day school teachers to emulate his good work.

I would recommend that he be given an increase of $100 from the beginning of the next fiscal year.

Mistawasis, March 8th 1891.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your favor of the 11th ult., file No. 117004/1, I have to say, that although your letter was a pleasant surprise to me, yet, that owing to the holding of a series of evangelistic services on this Reserve and vicinity, I could not at once send you an answer. These services, which were of great interest to the Indians, and highly appreciated by them, and were not we believe without profitable results to them, were brought to a close yesterday, the 7th inst.

As to the Mistawasis School, and the satisfactory results mentioned by Inspector Chisholm, I do not know that I can lay claim to any special credit for what has been accomplished. I have done my part as faithfully and conscientiously as possible, but it is comparatively easy to build upon a good foundation, and either as the policy of our Church, or as due to fortunate circumstances, this school has had the great advantage of a succession of good teachers. Miss McTagg, Miss McIntosh, Miss Gillespie and Miss Moore, were all highly competent teachers, and most devoted to their work. As for myself, I have had normal training and many years experience in teaching.

With regard to my methods of work I may state briefly some of our daily exercises and how conducted:

Opening. Usually sing a hymn and then read a few verses of the Scriptures or repeat a verse in concert. Every more difficult word is briefly explained.

Class Work. The programme of studies for Indian schools is followed as closely as possible.

Reading. Use the powers or sounds of the letters not the names in teaching beginners. Explain the meaning of every doubtful word, or have the pupils to explain them.

Composition or expression. Question pupils about the passage read. Try to get oral answers. Write questions on the lessons, or on subjects of general knowledge, on the blackboard and have the pupils write answers on their slates. Try to get the more advanced ones to write out short, simple stories, told them or read to them.

Writing. Practice first on slates then on copy-books.

Arithmetic. Counting, ball-frame, mental Arithmetic and slate-work.

Government. Use gentleness and kindness as far as possible, harsher methods only when really necessary. Never inflict corporal punishment for ignorance or dulness; reserve it exclusively for viciousness, or what is morally degrading.

Treat all alike, show no partiality.

Try to train them in habits of industry. Have charge of work, but, if possible, allow no idleness.

Praise them for good work and seek to develop their confidence in themselves and self-respect.

Order. Aim at cultivating orderly ways and prompt obedience. Have books and slates etc., taken out and put away quietly and quickly by a ring or two of the hand-bell. So also use the bell for rising out of seats, turning about and moving out of school at
recess or close of session. Have a little simple drill in this work occasionally. Also, occasionally, have in fine weather, a little outdoor drill in lining up in order, facing right or left and moving into school in an orderly manner.

Winter Work. The best results in school work are obtained during the winter when the children are kept in the Boarding Home or Children's Home. This building which is an annex of the Manse, and nearly as large, is connected with the main building by a kitchen. Here the Indian children, especially those whose homes are at a distance, are kept during the week from Monday morning till Friday afternoon. For the maintenance of the children and the services of a woman the Women's Foreign Missionary Society of our Church allows a grant of $175. The whole of this amount is seldom used, the actual expense being scarcely $150. Besides this the same society furnishes clothing for the children, and also sends quilts, etc., for the purchase of wood for fuel for the home.

In warm weather the Indian children return to their homes, and at school at that time receive only a mid-day meal of biscuits (provided by the Department) and milk or tea. Occasionally, for a change, give them loaf bread. And on account of the nomadic ways of their parents, as the attendance falls off from the winter's average, in order to encourage attendance give now and again a treat of nuts and candy. In winter we have a regular and large attendance of the Indian pupils, and with the wholesome and ample supply of food furnished them, and careful supervision as regards cleanliness and general health and recreation, the result is seen in the general good health of the pupils.
And the moral influence and home-like care they receive all tend to their improvement in manners and morals and in their acquaintance with the English language.

There are other things which might be mentioned which have no doubt had a good effect upon these children. I refer to certain improvements which were suggested and which by the prompt attention of the Agent, Mr. Borthwick and the clerk, Mr. Jackson, were soon brought about.

The School House. The outside walls were willowed and rough-cast. That is plaster with sand in it was spread over a lathing of willows. This has greatly improved the appearance of the building. The building is always kept clean by sweeping and scrubbing.

The Interior. The inside walls were whitewashed, and maps, pictures, etc., were placed around the tinted room.

The Grounds are always kept tidy.

Outbuildings. Instead of one water closet with two apartments, have had two built at the rear of the school, the doors facing in opposite directions, that of the boys' closet to the south, that of the girls' to the north. These buildings are a good distance apart.

From what is here stated I trust that the Department may have the information they desire. It is very gratifying to me to know that my work in this school and in behalf of the Indian children has met with the approval of the Inspector and of the Department.

Yours sincerely,

C. L. Bryden

Sir:

Your letter of the 31st ult., file No. 117094/1 was received by last mail.

In reply, as regards the bad roads, I may say, that in the spring, when the snow is going away, there is always a time here when the trail is sloppy and more or less muddy; and this year, on account of the very late spring, the period of bad roads was longer than usual. Then, in June, from the 16th to the 25th, or for nearly a fortnight, we had very rainy weather. The roads were then somewhat muddy, but most feature over the long grass bordering and along the trail. The children could not then pass back and forth along the way without getting their feet and ankles wet, and the girls, when they did come to school, had their bedraggled skirts clinging to their legs.

It would not be necessary, I think, to do anything toward improving the roads, which are fairly good; and to cut down the long grass and small bushes along the way, probably, would not greatly improve the roads for those who have to walk over them in wet weather.

In my opinion, some arrangement for the transport of the children is what is most needed. I have repeatedly at such times gone for some of the younger pupils, but as I have only a buggy and one horse I could do no more than take to the school a few who were not too far away.

Sir,

Referring to your letter of 23rd ult.

No. 117094/1, regarding the transport of school pupils to and from the Mistawasis Day school, I have the honor to report that I have not yet succeeded in securing permanent arrangements even under the latest and quite generous offer of the Department.

There are parties with whom I could make arrangements; but they have no horses to use. I have therefore to suggest, as a means of overcoming the difficulty, the purchase by the Department of suitable driving teams which could then be supplied to the Indians doing the work on sale under terms requiring the monthly repayment of a portion of the cost until the whole was paid.

The work is being performed temporarily by Jacob Johnstone for the North, and by George Dreaver for the children from the South of the school; but the arrangement is understood to be terminable on short notice by the Indians, and I wish to be prepared to meet the exigency should either or both of these parties cease the work. The cost of a suitable team and harness would probably be not less than $328.00 and the sum of $12.50 or $15.00 could be retained from each month's earnings by the Department until the full amount was repaid.

An arrangement of this nature would be effective in securing the permanence of the transport. The ownership of the team would remain vested in the Department until paid for, and the Indian would understand that his ultimate possession of them would depend upon his faithful continuance in the work and that all payments made upon them would be forfeited by his failure to keep his contract.

The authority is only requested to meet a possible emergency. It may not be required until after the first of April, and I have therefore to ask that if the idea commends itself to the judgement of the Department, the authority be made to extend to the fiscal year 1910-1911, in case the necessity for the purchase does not arise before.

I have the honor to remain,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

No. 17094/1, and the evident desire of the Department to make the Mistawasis Day School successful, I have the honor to respectfully suggest that no child of school age should be transferred from the Mistawasis reserve to the Duck Lake or any other boarding school without my special recommendation and for sufficient reason.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

Some of the statements in the Returns from this School, for last quarter, will doubtless be a disappointment to the Department of Indian Affairs, in view of the number of children who returned to this Reserve, when the Regina School was closed. A word of explanation, therefore, is necessary, in order that it may be understood why the average attendance was not so large as at first expected.

1. School Accommodation was not sufficient. The attendance at the School was so increased for a few days after the return of the pupils, that not only was every seat filled, but new seats had to be provided. As it was then believed that it would be impossible to take in all who had returned, who were expected to return, it was decided to limit the attendance to just those of school age, that is, to children from six to sixteen, and to allow no whites or non-Indian pupils to attend. On account of this decision, the larger boys of seventeen years and

VERY POOR COPY
were told that they would have to wait until some provision could be made for them. All these lads would have attended if room could have been found for them. When they found that they could not then be admitted, they did not long remain idle; they all, with the exception of one who was on the sick list, soon got employment, as there was work for them on the Reserve.

Then, with only those of school age in attendance, there were causes, afterwards, tending to reduce the average, which may be here mentioned:

1. An epidemic of la grippe, which lasted nearly a fortnight, and which seemed to affect nearly every Indian family on the Reserve, caused a serious reduction in the attendance at that time.

2. On three days, the children living south of the School, and who form the larger number in attendance, were not taken to School on account of the absence of their usual driver, who had gone to Duck Lake to meet his own and other children, who were returning from Regina.

3. A couple of children, from Roman Catholic homes, who had been in attendance for some time, left this School with the intention of entering the Indian Industrial School at Duck Lake.

4. Two boys, one a particularly bright lad, had to leave School for a time on account of scrofulous sores. This was in accordance with the Doctor's orders.

5. There has been, as is always the case here in summer, more or less irregularity on the part of a few, who
I have been away with their parents Senega digging or visiting.

It may be asked, what is the prospect for attendance when the school reopens after the summer holidays?

As soon as accommodation can be provided for them there should be the following numbers in attendance, grouping them by standards:

| Standard | Number |
|----------|--------|
| I        | 20     |
| II       | 8      |
| III      | 8      |
| IV       | 2      |
| V        | 1      |
| VI       | 1      |
| Total    | 40     |

In order to keep up the attendance when school reopens I would suggest that:

1. There should be, for the future, more stringent regulations for the compulsory attendance of some of the children, particularly in the case of those who are taken away on visits by their parents and others, and also in the case of those who go Senega digging, though they are more excusable, as the children can then be of material help to their parents in this industry, by which they are able to earn considerable, since the dried root is worth 40¢ per lb.

2. An assistant teacher to take charge of the youngest children (students) is very advisable, in order to secure the best results with the least delay, and as soon as a suitable building on place for the work can be provided.

Yours very sincerely,

C.V. Bryden.

Sir:—In my letter of July 12th, I called the attention of the Department to the prospect for attendance at this school after the summer holidays. On the roll for the quarter ending in June there were 35 names, and there seemed to be the probability that by the coming of some of the larger pupils, who had returned from Regina, there would be at least 40 names on the roll. But as the elder boys got work on the Reserve soon after they returned, and as they seemed to prefer their freedom and an open air life to the confinement of the class room, I made no effort to secure their attendance at school. Last quarter there were 28 names on the roll, so the average attendance was 16.39. For the quarter preceding there were 35 names on the roll and an average of 16.87. Of those on the rolls during the past year, several circumstances have conspired to prevent their regular attendance; as for instance, the severe illness of the following, or the menace of their disease to others:

Wm. LaBlanc was at home through scrofulous sore eyes for - 11 weeks
Marie Bird through scrofulous glands - 10 weeks
Gilbert Wolf - through tubercular affection - 9 weeks
Mary Duncan - through scrofulous glands - 5 weeks
Hannah Badger - do 4 weeks

The larger girls are becoming useful to their mothers, and when the latter are indisposed or on special occasions, these girls are kept from school to assist in housekeeping. The larger boys also are frequently kept from school to assist their fathers in their work; for instance, Richard Cardinal was detained by his father to assist in chores and the cutting of wood for 32 school days. Edward Campbell was detained by his father for 7 weeks, because the parent required the boy to do chores. In the latter case the teacher sent a note to the father complaining of the boy's non-attendance. In reply Jas. Campbell enquired whether the boy belonged to the teacher or to himself, and asserted that he would keep the boy at home when he chose, and only allow him to attend school when it suited himself. In such a case there would seem to be room for a compulsory attendance law.

During three days of severe
During three days of severe cold weather and one day through the death of the Chief's wife, only George Drewer's team conveyed children to the school, and the average for those 4 days was only 3.75.

All the above circumstances took place during the past quarter ended March 31st, 1912. In previous quarters similar reasons prevented fullest attendance, and all as shown were beyond the control of the teacher. But for these, the attendance during the period of transportation would have been much larger, and the benefits of that system were much more apparent.

The results as disclosed by this investigation have convinced myself, and will I trust satisfy the Department of the great improvement in the attendance of the pupils which has followed the introduction of transport facilities for school children on the Mistawasis reserve, and which in my judgment will fully justify the extension of the same system to the Sturgeon Lake and Sandy Lake reserves.

Regarding the use of the dormitories, I have to state that the teacher and his wife are most willing to keep the children of any Indians who desire to leave their homes for hunting, root-digging or berrying. The trouble is that most of the Indians who follow those pursuits desire the assistance of their children, say nothing of their intention; but simply move away with their families, and the first intimation to the teacher is the absence of the children from the school. On one occasion last summer, the teacher spoke to his wife of the great improvement which he noticed in Neta Badger through an unusually steady attendance. The next day the child was taken away by her father Philip Badger, and was absent until his trip was over. As a natural consequence, the child lost ground through that absence.

No marked success is possible with any children, Indian or white, whose...
Indian or white, whose attendance is fitful, and unless attendance is made compulsory, no teacher can rightly be held responsible for poor results in such cases.

Should the dormitories be required, some fittings will be found necessary, and I enclose herewith a requisition from the matron for articles which will be required if sleeping accommodation and farther meals are to be provided for Indian children left by their parents.

Regarding this list, I would prefer single iron bedsteads instead of the folding beds asked for. The actual air space of the dormitories is only sufficient according to the usual scale for about 3 boys and 3 girls; but during the summer when the windows may be kept open about five could be accommodated of each sex.

I have the honor to remain,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

A few weeks ago a paper expressing dissatisfaction with my work as a teacher, signed by the Chief and Head-Men of this Band, was sent to you.

I may say that with the exception of Jacob Johnstone, the chief, and George Dreamer, the ex-Chief, neither of whom can either read or write, not one of those whose names are given has ever been inside the school while teaching, and that not one of them is capable of forming a fair judgment either as regards the teachers' work or the progress of the pupils.

Trouble began when I found fault with the irregularity of the drivers in the transportation of the children. That, in my opinion, is the real cause of the action taken by the Indians. Though in all probability there was some outside influence brought to bear upon them supporting the course taken.

There was an improvement in the driving when they were told that a daily record of their arrival, etc., was being kept. This was seen especially in October, when there was fine weather, and the average attendance was the largest in the history of the school. Irregularity again became the rule when very cold weather came on. The climax of unsatisfactory work was reached in January. The school was then supposed to open at 9:30 A.M. and close at 5:30 P.M. The enclosed copy of the driving return for January will show you how the drivers did their work. In February the Chief had the document prepared.
which was sent to the Department. I saw what was said to be a draft of that paper. In it there were no specific charges, it dealt in generalities, such as... The teacher was too advanced in years for the work, the children were not making progress, my teaching was not up to the standard. Remember that only two of them can read either read or write, but only three of them can speak English; I am out of the teaching work, but from what I have stated the Department may judge as to the value of the teacher forwarded by the Chief, who had been very friendly feeling for me, since I could count with the Chief as a "third force," if not a fourth.

Your obedient servant,

Charles W. Bayden

Sir:

We are in receipt of a communication from Mr. S.A. Milligan, Agent, in which he says among other things that he is writing Ottawa asking if it is their intention to dispense with the mid-day meal in connection with the above school.

We respectfully but earnestly urge the Dept. that this should not be done, because doing away with the mid-day meal would virtually mean the closing of the school, measured as this meal means a very important factor in the life of our Indian children.

The closing of this Improved Day School is neither necessary nor desirable. The school has suffered during the past year in point of attendance five pupils, three of whom were our most regular attendants; were taken to Onion Lake Boarding School and two have died. Notwithstanding this depletion we have still upon the Roll twenty (20) Indian Children. Within a radius of two miles there are nineteen. In November the school was closed for nearly a month on account of an epidemic of Measles from which every child on the Reserve was afflicted. Some of these have not been able to return to school except for a few days on account of sore eyes, convulsions and Eczema.
Nevertheless our attendance has had an average of about ten, five of whom are in standard I and are making excellent progress. (See Report of School in last Annual Report.) Mr. Graybie, the Inspector, has not yet visited the school.

The greatest item in maintenance is the cost of transportation of the pupils to and from school. This difficulty might be obviated by bringing two families living two miles south of the school, to some point north, in which case the cost of transportation would be saved by one-half. This I have suggested to the Agent.

The closing of the school would be an act of injustice to the Presbyterian Church of Canada. For nearly forty years our Church has steadily maintained balances upon this Reserve at a maximum cost. These children belong to our Mission—we feel a responsibility in regard to them. The closing of the school would involve an additional cost to the Church of four hundred dollars. If anything is done by the Dept., which will render it more difficult for the Church to carry on its work unimpaired—a work upon which they have spent many thousands—I have little doubt but that the Church will feel aggrieved.

As teacher and missionary we are doing the work of two upon the salary of one. Our work in the Missionary as well as...
in the Educational department has during the past year shown greater advancement financially and in other ways than for many years. The children have been comfortably clothed for school and church and present a gratifying appearance in point of neatness and cleanliness not to be excelled in ordinary white schools. The aged and destitute have also received clothing. The able-bodied, the majority of whom have attended Boarding Schools, are treated as men capable of earning their living, not as paupers. They too have endeavored to cultivate a spirit of industry and manifest self-reliance. In this mode of procedure authorized by the W.M.S. of our Church, the Indians took exception, but adhering strictly to the instructions, they are falling into line.

Hoping that the Dept. will favorably consider our request and thus continue the means by which we can secure great efficiency in our work,

Shall the honor be, Sir,

At a meeting of the Presbytery of Prince Albert, held in St. Paul's Church, Prince Albert, on Tuesday, the Eleventh day of February, 1917, the following resolution was passed in protest against recent actions on the part of the Indian Agent at Mistawasis and the Department of Indian Affairs at Ottawa, which are affecting, in a most disastrous way, the work of the Church's Mission at Mistawasis.

It was moved, seconded, and unanimously carried that the Presbytery enter its strongest protest against:

1. Recruiting by the authorities of Boarding Schools controlled by other denominations of children belonging to the Presbyterian Mission at Mistawasis. During the past few years, nine children, who had been cared for by the Presbyterian Church, were removed with the consent of the Agent, to either Anglican or Roman Catholic Boarding Schools, thus most seriously reducing the attendance and efficiency of the Day-School at Mistawasis.

2. The reduction of grants from the Government to provide for the salary of House Matron and her assistant. The services of a House Matron are absolutely essential for the work of supervision and instruction in Domestic Science among the children on the Reserve.

3. The suggested discontinuance of the mid-day meal now provided by the Department, which would be fatal to the attendance of the children at the Day-School and injurious as well to the health of the children, who in most instances, get no nourishing food other than that provided in this meal.

Sir,

I have the honor to report on a subject that has been causing considerable friction for the past six months, that is, the Missionary work on this reserve.

I have refrained from saying anything, as I have been told in plain language by Mr and Mrs Smith that it is a thing over which I have no control, in the capacity of Indian Agent, and I can assure you that I am not at all anxious to, or looking for more work than I have at the present time.

Some months ago at a meeting of the Band, at which Mr Smith was present, the Indians asked him to resign as missionary, to this of course he positively refused, the consequence was the meeting, to use the most charitable construction ended, without prayer.

My sympathies at the time were with Mr Smith and knowing the Revd Colin Young, Superintendent of Presbyterian Missions personally, I wrote him a private letter, asking him to make a visit, and try and adjust the difference between the Indians and Mr Smith, to this he agreed, but owing to sickness did not arrive until last Monday, when he called a meeting in the Church.

Dear Mr. Edmison:

As instructed by the Board at the regular meeting in March I visited the Indian Mission at Mistawasis and beg to report as follows:

(1) The church building has been greatly improved in every way since Rev. J. E. Smith took charge. The cost of these improvements has been borne entirely by the Mission.

(2) The services on Sunday have not been better attended, perhaps, in the history of the Mission.

(3) The progress in the Day-school of the children has been excellent and has been most satisfactory to the Government Inspector.

(4) In spite of all this, there has grown a spirit of antagonism between the Mission and the agent, due largely to the indifference of the agent to any work done by the Church and also to an over aggressive attitude of the missionaries.

(5) This antagonism has spread among the Indians, partly I should say, because of the attitude of the agent toward the Mission and partly because the missionaries insisted on the sale of blankets giving some return for the clothing they were demanding from the Mission.

(6) Most serious of all is the threat of the agent that the School may be closed at the end of June and the few children now attending sent to Boarding Schools on other reserves. In all probability, these Schools would belong to other denominations and the children would be educated away from the Presbyterian Church into some other communion. This would effectually destroy any future prospect for our Mission.

In view of the above facts, would recommend that no change be made at present at Mistawasis, or until the policy of the Government has been stated definitely in regard to the School. Should the Government persist in the determination to close the School, there seems to be no alternative but to withdraw our Missionaries and to close our Mission. At the same time the responsibility of any such action should be thrown on the Government as through their action our Mission work would be made impossible.

Yours most faithfully,

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

The Rev. Mr. Edmison, Secretary of the Board of Home Missions of the Presbyterian Church, has forwarded a resolution passed at the meeting of the Presbytery of Prince Albert approving of the resignation of the Rev. J. E. Smith, missionary on the Mistawasis Indian Reserve, and advising the Home Mission Board that no further appointment be made to this field. The resolution states that several reasons for abandoning the Indian work there were carefully considered and that, while regretting the closing of the mission, it is obliged to take the present step because of official hampering and lack of scope for further profitable effort.

The resolution also states that it is notorious fact that the Indian Agent at Mistawasis is not in sympathy with the work and that a strong protest against some of his actions had been submitted to the Department without any encouraging response.

This is rather strong language to use against the Agent, as it is unsupported by any evidence of his antagonism to
to the work of the missionary on the reserve.

The Rev. Mr. Smith, the missionary, was also the teacher of the day school on the reserve, having been appointed to that position on the 21st of September, 1914, and it was only in connection with the school work that Mr. Agent Milligan came in official contact with him.

Mr. Smith failed to make a success of the school and when the attention of the Presbyterian Church authorities was called to the falling off in the attendance and the excessive cost of maintenance they came back at the Department with a report prepared by the Rev. Colin G. Young, Superintendent of Presbyterian Missions, in which he states that there has grown up a spirit of antagonism between the mission and the Agent, due largely to the indifference of the Agent to any work done by the church, and also to an over aggressive attitude of the missionaries and he blames the Agent for threatening to close the school.

The facts are that the Rev. Mr. Smith failed to win the confidence of the Indians in his mission work and they were so dissatisfied with him that the Agent wrote the Rev. Mr. Young a private letter asking him to visit the reserve and try and adjust the difference between the Indians and
and Mr. Smith. I think this shows conclusively that the Agent was doing his best to assist the missionary. As far as the school work is concerned, the Agent was acting under the instructions of the Department, which were that, if better results could not be obtained, this school was to be closed.

Neither the Department nor the Agent are responsible for the failure of Mr. Smith to secure the confidence and cooperation of the Indians in his missionary work on the reserve and it is a poor defence of his unfitness for the dual position he occupied on the Mistawasis Reserve to attribute his want of success to the Agent.

He has never been successful as a teacher, though a steady and man, & he is now tired of trying to do work that is beyond his powers. So you see there are three schools to be supplied. The only man I can think of is J.R. Selte; I know he is not a competent teacher for Forteau Lake, but the Dept. wishes him to accept it. As I think I told you, he would like to try Mistawasis, & perhaps the change...
stir him up to a little fresh effort, he might do better work there. On failing that, he might accept Kinowmootayao's school, Big River. He would do better than Louis Shemakon, & the children there are very backward. I would like to know soon what the Dept. wishes under these circumstances. I do not think there is a very suitable residence for teacher (White-man) at either Dumont Lake or Big River. I am sorry I can not promise more, but I can not make a coat without cloth.

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott.

The Superintendent of Indian Education has drawn attention to the very satisfactory work which is being performed by Mrs. Le Clair, teacher of the Mistawasis Indian Day School. This is a large improved day school, and midday meals are served to the pupils. There are 24 children of school age on the Reserve, within 3 miles of the school, 20 of whom are enrolled, with an average attendance of 11.

Mrs. Le Clair is an excellent teacher, and has a 2nd class professional permanent certificate for the Province of Saskatchewan, and is also an Old Country certificated teacher. She is liked by all on the Reserve - Indians, children and the agent. Mr. Ferrier states she is devoting her life to Indian work, but finds, if more financial assistance is not given, it will be necessary for her to take up other work. She is at present in receipt of a salary at the rate of $600 per annum and bonus at rate of $150, which makes a combined salary and bonus of $750. I may say that we are paying teachers having her qualifications in the western provinces salaries as high as $900 and also the bonus. I consider that we should endeavour to keep teachers of this class in our service, and, no doubt, the salary she receives is too low for the work she is performing. I would, therefore, beg to recommend that she be given an increase of at least $200 per annum, which will allow her a salary of $800, and that such increase dates from the first of the present school year, viz: September 1st, last.

Extract from Inspector's Report on the Day Schools in the Carlton Agency. April 4, 1923. Original on 107-9-6.

MISTAWASIS DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on March 29th, and found only two girls present out of an enrolment of 16. The average attendance for the quarter was 4.9. The pupils are all in the primary grades. With one exception their ages range from five to nine years.

A number of reasons are given for the poor attendance; severe weather, sickness and distance from the school being the chief reasons given.

I am of the opinion, however, that the real trouble can be attributed to a lack of interest on the part of the parents. At least 16 children of school age reside within a radius of three miles. The parents do not move about much during the winter months and if they were at all interested in obtaining an education for their children they could find a means of getting them to school.

Mrs. Kate Le Clair is in charge as teacher; she has a second class Saskatchewan certificate.

To carry on this school under the present attendance conditions is a waste of money for no good purpose. I believe that the attendance could be materially increased by engaging the services of a driver to bring in the children from the north of the agency and by engaging a teacher of more forcible character than Mrs. Le Clair.

The teacher's residence is a large frame building and one of the rooms is used as a classroom. It is very comfortable and fairly well equipped with school furniture.

W. Murison,
Insp. of Ind. Agencies.

MISTAWASIS DAY SCHOOL.

This school was opened on September 1st by the Rev. W. Moore, who has been appointed as missionary on this reserve by the Continuing Presbyterian Church. Mr. Moore's mother, who is 70 years of age or over, does the greater part of the teaching. She taught, she tells me, in the Portage la Prairie Boarding School 40 years ago.

The children are boarding at the school from Monday until Friday. Mr. Moore undertook to do this work if allowed the amount of the former teacher's salary, $840.00 per annum. This amount is furnished by the church. He tells me he receives some help from the people and has to bear the balance himself as he finds that $840.00 per annum does not nearly meet the expense. There were 7 boys and 8 girls in residence on the day of my visit.

Two small rooms, 14 x 14, with an 8 ft. ceiling, are used as dormitories. There are six single beds in each dormitory. The beds are very comfortable and are provided with springs, mattresses and counterpanes. In each room there is one wash basin and a separate towel for each child. These dormitories are separated by a room between them which is occupied by Mrs. Moore. Separate narrow stairways lead from each of these small dormitories downstairs, the girls' stairway terminating at the back entrance of the school. The boys' stairway lands in the room now used as a class room, and in order to get out of the building, they would have to pass through the class room and a cloakroom where there is a small heating stove installed. The main building is heated with a hot air furnace. A small gravity water tank is installed in the attic.

The dormitories do not provide sufficient air space for the number of children sleeping in them, and are, I feel, unsafe from a health standpoint. Mrs. Moore stated that she...
MISTAWASIS DAY SCHOOL (Cont'd.)

that she could spare two more rooms, if necessary, to give more air space.

There is no fire fighting equipment in this building and if a fire should break out during the night time, it is very doubtful, in my opinion, if the children could be safely got out of the building. It looks like a fire trap to me, and I am reporting fully in connection with this matter as I do not know on whom the responsibility would rest if anything happened.

I may mention that of the children in attendance, 4 are the children of non treaty halfbreeds. Of the children, 3 are 6, 5 are 7, 2 are 8, 1 is 9, 3 are 10 and 1 is 11 years of age. Of those attending, at least 7 are within reasonable walking distance of the school.

I may say that two or three years ago, this band was in favour of closing up their day school and sending the children to boarding schools. I think they have been influenced in this new move by the missionary. In fact, the missionary takes the stand that it is through the children that they hope to get results from their work, and they are hoping to have the Department take over and assume the expense of the school. I was asked if I would recommend this, but did not give them any encouragement. I simply stated that I would report the facts to the Department as I found them.

Dear Sir,

I have been absent from Canada for four months on a visit to the Mission Fields of the Presbyterian Church in the Orient. On my return I found a little difficulty has arisen in regard to the Mistawasis Reserve. The facts are these:

This Reserve is in the hands of the Presbyterian Church in Canada, and the Mission work is under the Church Board. There had formerly been a day school on the Reserve, which had been closed for two years. Rev. Mr. Moore and his mother are in charge of the Mission, and Mr. Moore being a qualified teacher, thought to reopen the day school, but found some of the children living too far away from the school and were too young to go and come each day. His house was big enough and his mother only too willing to have them stay all night. Accordingly, he wrote the Women's Missionary Society, under whose care all School work is, and they, seeing in it only an opportunity for service, agreed to lend the scheme their support. They sent in some supplies and then wrote the Department asking them to consider renewing the grant formerly given to the day school. There was no thought, I take it, to open a boarding school in the accepted sense, simply as the parents were anxious to have their young children go to school, to give them a day school and in addition care for those too young to come and go. I think perhaps our Board went the wrong way about this, but if so it was only through lack of knowledge of procedure, and quite unintentional. I regret if any mistake has occurred.

I would like to ask if the Department is absolutely opposed to reopening a day school, letting those near the Mission come and go each day, and only those who are too far away and too young to come and go, remain with Mrs. Moore for the nights. Would the
department be opposed even should we ask no grant from them, provided the Indian Agent on the Reserve were satisfied that there was no overcrowding, &c.? If so, the matter will have to be dropped and I will tell the Rev. Mr. Moore so. These children are too young for the Indian Residential Schools and it does seem an opportunity.

Regretting any mistake that may have been made,

here we hope to show by this communication.

That there are now sufficient pupils who can and will attend will be evident when we point out that though the Department had no school in operation, there were seventeen pupils of school age available, who were enrolled and attended classes held pending the decision of the Department. Dear Mrs. McKerroll:

With reference to recent correspondence and pursuant to our conversation of the 29th ultimo, I wish to inform you that I have received reports from Mr. Indian Commissioner Graham of Regina and Mr. Indian Agent Weir. I have written to our officers, repeating the authority for an Indian day school, as indicated in my letter to you of September 27th, last. Dear Mr. Graham:

Knowing that you have given much time and thought to the situation on the Mistawasis Reserve I beg to submit to you the following matters supplementing the matters contained in the longer letter that I enclose. The longer letter is addressed to the Department of Indian Affairs through you, as Indian Commissioner. I trust that this is the proper procedure. If the procedure is not correct will you give effect to the desire of the proposals made and speed forward the suggestions according to the proper method.

(1) In order to know whether the Indians would endorse the proposals re the loan of the trust funds in the care of the Government I have submitted the proposal to them. On Sunday, Dec 16th the Chief and his Council unanimously agreed to the proposal that the government through the Indian department be authorized to make a loan of the necessary funds from these trust funds on the understanding that the government take advantage of the earliest opportunity to provide through the estimates for the securing of these funds in order to replace the money thus borrowed in the Indian Trust Fund account. This is a method of speeding up the work and meeting an urgent situation.

(2) Chief Drever is willing that his children be replaced in the Onion Lake Boarding school of the Church of England till provision can be made to take care of them and others like them on the Mistawasis reserve along the line suggested in the letter enclosed. He makes the request that they be allowed to remain at home till after the Christmas holidays. As the holidays are almost here I imagine that there will be no difficulty in this connection. The chief has shown a good spirit in this matter and is ready to co-operate in every way in order to meet the need that he and the other Indians feel for the education of their children under the care of the Presbyterian church.

(3) Mrs J. W. Moore who has been for many years on this reserve as a missionary assures me that accommodation for approximately 12 children in the readjusted present building will meet the need for the present and for many years to come and in her judgment is a better solution than the building of a large boarding school under present conditions. After having visited the school, the Indians, and gone carefully into the matter this is the way it appears to me.

It seems to me that this is all that need be added to the longer letter in the way of supplementary information.

With the best of good wishes and trusting to hear a favourable report, and with the seasons greetings, Yours sincerely,

(Sgd) W. G. Brown
The Department of Indian Affairs
Ottawa
per Mr. W. M. Graham, Commissioner for Indian Affairs
Regina

Gentlemen:

A situation has arisen on the Mistawasis reserve in this Province about which I would like to write you in some detail. My own position is that of minister of St. Andrews Presbyterian Church, Saskatoon, and convenor of the Committee that has charge of all the mission work of the Presbyterian Church within this Province.

Our missionary on the reserve is the Rev. William Moore who is a graduate of the University of Saskatchewan and graduate of the Provincial Normal school. Associated with him is his mother, Mrs. J. W. Moore who with her husband, was in charge of the missionary work on this reserve for a period of probably twenty-five years. At the present time there is a qualified teacher recently sent out by the Women's Missionary society of the Presbyterian Church in Canada whose headquarters are in Toronto, the President of the Society being Mrs. H. M. Strachan.

The Indians on this reserve are very strong in their convictions and are most earnest in their desire to have their children brought up in the Presbyterian Faith.

On this reserve, as you know, is a large frame building with large rooms for bedrooms, a full size basement and appears to be in a good state of repair. Last year an inspector of the department visited this reserve and made an inspection of this building. I ought to have said that the Presbyterian Church made an application to your department for a boarding school on this reserve in 1927. Our representatives reported that they had been told that this was possible at this present time, but it was agreed that we should have an approved day school and certain children were to be allowed to be taken in residence in this large frame building. Mr. Moore was then the teacher of the school. The inspector found that the children were too much crowded in their sleeping rooms, that there was not suitable protection in case of fire and certain other defects I understand.

The zeal of the Indians is now seen in the fact that they have set to work and built a log school house with sleeping accommodation for the boys upstairs and I understand that Mrs. Moore and the new teacher will be allowed to accommodate some of the girls in the large frame building in which the Moores and the teacher now live.

The children of the Chief George Drever and of William Drever his son were at the church of England school at Onion Lake last year. This year some of these children were sent to the File Hills school of the United Church. As I have already said this does not meet the earnest desire of the Indians who are most anxious to have their children brought up in their own faith. Their building of the log school house being an indication of this desire. Outside of the reserve we did not know of the building of this log school house. It does not seem to me to meet the situation.

May I just make this general observation. In the distribution of general property between the United Church of Canada and the Presbyterian Church in Canada the Presbyterian Church received, what I can only describe as a very raw deal. I will not enlarge on this nor are we going to sit down and whine about it. The condition of the Birtle school and the stripped condition of the Mistawasis reserve are sufficient evidence of the above. If we may have, as we have every reason to believe that we have, the sympathetic help of the department we intend to do some real work for our Indian fellow citizens.

Now for some suggestions.

(1) The large frame building lends itself I feel certain, as I have carefully examined it, to certain easily carried out repairs that will make it adequate to meet the needs of an approved day school with residence and adequate protection from fire for
a limited number of children and for all that this reserve is likely to need for a good many years. The number in residence need not be more than 10 or 12 so that it would not require more than the present staff to handle the work.

(2) Provision could be made to give all the children who come to the school their mid day meal.

(3) A suitable well ought to be provided without any further delay as it is now necessary for the people at the mission to bring all their drinking water from the agency which is about one mile distant. A good many years ago Mrs. Moore says that there was a suitable well with abundance of good water near the present mission buildings but for some reason it has been filled up and is of no use. This however indicates that water is probably available without great difficulty.

(4) The Indians feel that even if no provision has been made in the estimates for such repairs as above suggested that there is a large fund at the command of the department for the service of this band made available through the sale of lands. They are willing if no funds are available through the regular estimates to authorize your department to borrow the necessary funds from this reserve fund to carry out these repairs in an adequate way and at the first opportunity you could secure the funds from the approved estimates and repay the loan to this reserve fund for the special benefit of the Indians.

(5) In the case of the Drever children I understand that it is part of the procedure of the department that Indian children must be properly discharged from a school where they have been registered. In this case the Drever children should be properly discharged from the Onion Lake School. If you could undertake the above program after it was fully examined by some of your representatives, I believe that the Indians might agree to leave their children at Onion Lake till these repairs could be carried out if they were sure it would be done at the earliest date that would be reasonable, and when the accommodation was ready on their own reserve all their children could be handled on their own reserve.

If you could see your way to meet a situation that has caused the Indians a good deal of distress in such a way as has been suggested I believe that you will meet a real need and do a real service and in the work you will have the heartiest co-operation of the Presbyterian Church in Canada.

I am

Yours respectfully,

(Sgd) W. G. Brown

St. Andrews Presbyterian Manse
Saskatoon, Dec. 5th, 1928.

Dear Doctor Scott,

May I inform you that our Board has engaged Miss Sadie Mcqueen of Stayner, Ontario, to take charge of the school at Mistawasis Indian Reserve. She leaves for her position on Tuesday, the 20th, and we expect that the Day School will be in full operation shortly after her arrival. She is well qualified for this work, holding second class professional certificates, having had many years' experience and having also been in charge of arranging noon luncheons in a rural school for a period of time. Her references and credentials are very good, and we are pleased to be able to report her appointment.

May I ask you if the $60.00 a month which you spoke to us about in regard to salary, is for ten months of the year or for twelve months. We shall be glad if you will send us this information. Also, does the Government supply any needed text books for the children, or do we have to do that?

In a letter which I had from Mr. Moore of Mistawasis, he mentions the Indians hauling logs for a building. No request has gone to the Reserve from Toronto for any building. Can you tell me if you have any knowledge of what this is for, as the letter I wrote inquiring has not yet been replied to, and we are wondering if the Government has asked that a School house or any other building should be built?

Thanking you for your interest,

Yours very sincerely,

Madam:

I have your letter with reference to the closing of the Mistawasis Indian Day School in June, 1926. For some time, the Department had seriously considered discontinuing the activity on account of the poor attendance. On March 22, of that year, the Department wrote to His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan that, as from June 30th, the school would remain closed indefinitely. One week later, the Department received a letter from His Lordship, which had crossed ours, recommending a change of teachers on May 15th. The Department replied, referring to the earlier letter announcing the closing of the school. In May, His Lordship suggested reconsideration, but the Department replied that the expenditure attendant upon the activity was unwarranted.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

June 19th, 1934.

Dr. H.W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

Mr. Moore from Mistawasis writes me that cheques have been reaching him from the Department for $75.00, marked April salary. May I ask if the cut has not applied to his salary? May I also enquire why a change has been made in the policy without notifying the Secretary here in that a cheque for salary has been sent direct instead of through me as Secretary of the Department? It may be that this has been an oversight or it may be a change of policy. Please send me information regarding the matter.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]
Secretary, Indian Department.

MCM/MR
Ottawa, June 25th, 1934.

Madam,

With reference to your letter of the 19th instant, I beg to say that, beginning in April, 1934, the Department is paying the salaries of teachers of Indian day schools monthly. I may, also, add that present regulations require that salaries of teachers be paid direct.

Owing to the fact that the 10% deduction on salaries does not now affect those earning less than $1,000 a year, Reverend Mr. Moore is being paid his full salary of $750.

I regret that you were not previously informed of these new arrangements.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
Secretary.

Mrs. D. T. L. McKerroll,
Women's Missionary Society
of the Presbyterian Church in Canada,
19 Laws St.,
Toronto 9, Ont.
The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa,
Canada.

Dear Sirs:

Would you be kind enough to let me know the exact amount of salary sent to Mr. W.W. Moore, of Mistawasis, Saskatchewan. I would be obliged for an early reply.

Thanking you,

Very sincerely yours,

(Mrs. D.H.) Mary C. McKee
Secretary, Indian Department.
Ottawa, April 17, 1936.

Dear Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 15th instant, Rev. W. W. Moore is being allowed salary at the rate of $750 a year as teacher at the Mistawasis Indian Day School. Payment is made on the basis of ten teaching months in the academic year.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Mrs. D. T. L. McKerroll,

Sir.— 

I have the honor to draw your attention to the condition of Mistawasis Indian Day School well. During the last few weeks the cribbing started to cave in, making it difficult to draw water, and very un-sanitary on account of mice etc. getting into the water through the wood spreading.

The cribbing is made up of inch lumber, and as the well appears to be old, I do not feel like taking the responsibility of sending a man down to make temporary repairs, as the slightest pressure may cause the whole well to cave in.

Under the circumstances I would recommend that authority be granted to sink a new well at an approximate cost of from $75.00 to $85.00.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.
