Inspector Hamilton's Report on Schools in the Carlton Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit the following report on the schools in the Carlton Agency, which I inspected during the month of September, 1930.

MISTAWASIS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.

On the day I visited this school, I found the Rev. Mr. Moore, the Presbyterian Minister, in charge, and was informed by him that the church authorities had recommended his appointment in place of Miss McQueen, who, I understand, taught last year and rendered excellent service.

This school was closed for a number of years, and when opened again, it was necessary to fix up the children's dining room, which is in the teacher's residence, for a classroom. The old log school was beyond repair. Mr. Moore and his mother have resided in the teacher's residence since his appointment four years ago as Missionary. Mrs. Moore provides the noon-day meal for the children, the requirements for which, I understand, are supplied by the church.

The present classroom is too small and has practically no available room for blackboard. The room is also insufficiently lighted and poorly ventilated. A new classroom is required, but I doubt if the cause

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
MISTAWASIS INDIAN DAY SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

if the cause, at the present time, justifies the expense of a new building. Above the present classroom are dormitories, originally built to accommodate the children at night during the week. At small cost, the partitions might be removed, giving a room 18x30, which room can be heated along with the residence, of which it forms a part.

The roll calls for 13 pupils, and all were present. The grades are as follows:

Grade I - 9
" II - 2
" III - 2

The children appeared somewhat shy, and I was not greatly impressed with the work as presented by Mr. Moore. The children were clean and tidy in appearance, and in most cases, fairly well clothed.

One of the toilets is in need of repair, the board fence separating the two should be re-built. Mr. Moore could not even inform me which was the boys' toilet, so I judged he took little interest in the affairs of the school.
Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report on the schools in the Carlton Agency, which was made by Mr. Hamilton.

You will note what he says regarding a new classroom on the Mistawasis Reserve. I do not think the Department would be warranted in spending anything at this school, as the time will come when these children should be removed to boarding schools.

The report on the Little Red River Day School is not very encouraging.

I quite agree with the Inspector that it would be out of the question to provide vans to haul the children to the Ahtahtakoops Day School.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 107-5-5, dated September 28th, with reference to the request of Indian Agent Davis that a new furnace be installed at the Mistawasis Indian Day School.

I beg to advise you that I am familiar with the condition of this furnace and I am satisfied that it is burned out and should be replaced. It was installed twenty-four years ago and has already served for some years beyond the natural life of a furnace. The Mistawasis, Sandy Lake, and Sturgeon Lake School residences were all built the same year and had the same type of furnace installed. The Sandy Lake furnace was replaced in 1926 and the Sturgeon Lake in 1927, both being burned out. The Mistawasis furnace I consider no longer safe.

The type of furnace I would recommend is a wood furnace of 40,000 cubic feet capacity. This is similar to the furnaces installed at Sturgeon Lake and Sandy Lake and they have proved quite satisfactory. The cost, installed, is about $280.00. The M. and P. Plumbing Company of Prince Albert are on the approved list, and they were the firm who installed the furnaces at Sandy Lake and Sturgeon Lake.

Your obedient servant,

Mistawasis Day School

I visited this school on February 23rd and found 7 Indian pupils present out of an enrollment of 13. The average attendance for the month to date was 5.3. I remained for some time in the classroom and watched the teacher at his work. I questioned some of the children and found that they answered my questions readily. They spoke up quite audibly when reading and appeared to be making progress in their work. The Reverend William Moore is the teacher. I found conditions rather better than on my previous visit.

The classes are being held in the wing attached to the school residence. This room is not ideal for a classroom, but it is considerably better than the log building which they have been using. The lighting could be improved upon by adding more windows. They are short of blackboard space. The blackboard in use is small and practically worn out. I would recommend that they be provided with Hyplate blackboard 14 feet long, which could be placed at the end of the room and would be much easier on the pupils' eyesight than the board now in use which is placed at the side of the room.

The school residence on this Reserve was built along the lines of the residence at Sturgeon Lake and Sandy Lake Reserves. It is provided with a wing with dormitories upstairs and a kitchen with the intention of using it as a semi-residential school. With a few alterations, I think the classroom could be made to serve the purpose very well and it would be unnecessary to put up a new building for classroom purposes.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant

Memorandum:

Mr. Hoey,

While I was in Regina I met Miss W. Moore who asked me to bring the following matters to your attention -

The noon meal at the Mistawasis School where her brother, Rev. W. Moore, teaches, is not sufficient for the pupils. She hoped that in future more food would be supplied in order to give the children a fair mid day meal.

She also mentioned that she was hiring a woman at $20.00 per month, to look after their own home, which is next door to the school. She suggested that this woman prepare and serve the mid day meal to the children, which would take up about half of her time, and the department pay half of her salary, namely $10.00 per month for the ten teaching months, for this service.

I made no promises to Miss Moore, other than to say I would bring the matters to your attention.

General Superintendent of Agencies.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of August 31 addressed to Dr. Robertson, Inspector of Indian Agencies, has reached the Department. In replying to Dr. Robertson we are pointing out that it was never the intention to serve what might be considered a full meal at any day school. It is our desire that only a nourishing light lunch be provided. Any other procedure would involve extra work for which present regulations do not permit us to pay and special equipment which is not available in day schools.

With this in mind it is felt that the amounts authorized for midday lunches at the schools in your Agency in official letter of September 16, 1938 are adequate with the possible exception of the Montreal Lake School where, I understand, the attendance at the present time is somewhat larger than it was in past years. If you consider it necessary you may increase the amount at Montreal Lake from $60.00 to $90.00.

In forwarding accounts you should send a separate account for each school and I am, therefore, returning your voucher No. 482 in order that you may comply with these instructions.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

With reference to the new school for the Mistawasis Reserve as outlined in your letter of January 10th, file 107-5-5; this school is very badly needed. The residence that is now used for the teacher is a very poor building and one that I would not consider worth spending much money on for repairs.

A single class room, about 26 x 30, would be about the right size, having a full basement that should be used for vocational training. I am returning the form which was enclosed with your letter containing the information desired. You will note that I have recommended that the school be built by contract, the reason being that it would be impossible for me to supervise the work if done by day labour owing to possible interference from Rev. Moore, the teacher, and his relatives.

However, I would like to suggest that the present office of this Agency be utilized for this school, the cost of altering same would be about $300.00, and that the present residence of the Agent be used as a residence for the teacher. At the present time this Agency office is located in a very poor place from an administration and economical viewpoint having been placed here years ago when the nearest railway was Duck Lake or Prince Albert. The office and staff could be moved to Prince Albert and occupy offices in the Federal Building, which point is the most logical and offers better train service and would save miles of unnecessary driving in order to meet trains and make connections. Further any supplies that have to be reshipped could be distributed more economically and easier from Prince Albert, instead of paying the freight to Leask and then back over the same lines.

If the above suggestion does not meet with your approval, would the Department consider taking down the present teacher's residence and building a smaller cottage. Some of the lumber could be used on the new building. The present residence is a big barn like structure containing 14 rooms.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis, Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Recently the Department wrote to Indian Agent Davis in order to obtain information required in connection with the proposal to erect, during the coming summer, a new day school on the Mistawasis Reserve. For your information I enclose a copy of his reply.

I wish, however, to direct your special attention to the second paragraph of Mr. Davis' letter. When you last visited Ottawa I believe that you stated that there was at least one Indian on the Mistawasis Reserve who was fully capable of supervising the erection of a school. Dear Sir:

Ref: Your 107-5-5 of February 9th,
School, Mistawasis Reserve.

I have again discussed this matter with Mr. Davis.

When in Ottawa, I recommended that the old building be dismantled and a school and teacherage built, using the material contained in the old school. Mr. Davis informs me that the old building, which is a very large one, was constructed to a large extent of short ends of lumber, a surplus from the other buildings; that while quite a large amount of this lumber could be salvaged and used in a new building, the amount is problematic.

It is now my opinion that we should build a new school, allowing the old building to stand for the present and using it for a teacher's residence until such time as money is available to build a teacherage.

As I stated when in Ottawa, the Chief of the Mistawasis Band is a first-class carpenter, and there are other fairly good workmen on the Reserve. In discussing this with Mr. Davis, I pointed this out to him and he did not hesitate to admit that the school could be built by the Indians. He, however, feared interference on the part of the teacher. I informed him that he was the Agent and would be held responsible for building, consequently I could not see why he could not carry this work on, and I instructed him to prepare a sketch of the proposed school, together with an estimate of the cost, and submit same.

Yours truly,

Thos. Robertson,

Dear Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to the new day school that the Department intends to erect this summer on the Mistawasis reserve.

I have showed the plans which you forwarded, to our Engineering Branch and it is considered that from a plan prepared by us a building could be erected at as reasonable a cost as from the plan you submitted. The plans of the building that we would forward to you would provide for two doors, one into each cloakroom. It appears from the plan which you forwarded that all persons going into the school would have to enter through the boys' cloakroom. This is a minor matter, but I am inclined to feel that two entrances are preferable. Possibly a slight alteration could be made in the plan which you forwarded in order to provide for two doors.

I note that your plan provides seating accommodation for only 30 children. If the figures appearing in the last census return are correct, it would appear that when building the school we should provide accommodation for 35 children, as the census figures indicate that the school population should increase. You might discuss this matter with Indian Agent Davis and let me know whether he agrees.

Memorandum: Mr. Wardle

Re: Indian Day School,
Mistawasis Reserve, Sask.

With reference to your memorandum of the last instant regarding the building proposed for the above, I am forwarding herewith, in duplicate, a sketch plan (see attached) of a building of the type which will provide the accommodation requested, namely, one classroom to seat 36 pupils with full basement.

You will note, however, that the classroom shown on this plan is for 40 pupils. I may say that a variation of 5 pupils can readily be made by eliminating one row of seats and reducing the length of the classroom by 2'6". Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Mistawasis Indian Day School,
Electoral District of Prince Albert,
Carlton Indian Agency,
Province of Saskatchewan.

An amount of $4,000.00 was provided in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1939-40 for the erection of a new school on the Mistawasis Reserve to replace the present school.

I have been in correspondence with Inspector Robertson and Indian Agent Davis in connection with the above and they recommend erection by day labour under the general supervision of the Agent.

A number of the Indians are practical tradesmen and they will be employed as far as possible.

Indian Agent Davis estimates that he can erect a school at a cost somewhat less than the amount provided in the appropriation.

In the past two years other buildings have been erected in the Carlton Agency under the general supervision of the Agent and these have proved very satisfactory and no unnecessary expenditure has been incurred.

I should, therefore, appreciate it if the Honourable the Minister would approve instructions being issued to Indian Agent Davis to proceed with the erection of the Mistawasis school as soon as weather conditions permit.
In the event of the Minister approving, the materials shown on the attached requisitions will be required and no doubt these requisitions will be forwarded to the Purchasing Agent by your office.

As I stated above Indians will be employed as far as possible but a white foreman, a brick layer and a plasterer will be required. I should appreciate your advising the names and addresses of the men whom you wish us to engage.

The Mistawasis Reserve is situated about ten miles from the town of Leask, Saskatchewan.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I am enclosing a requisition for materials for a new well at the Mistawasis Indian Day School. The present well, which is 80 feet deep, is dried up. It is only 30" square which makes it impossible to allow a man to work in it. Further the cribbing is in very poor shape and in a dangerous condition.

As this well cannot be repaired the only alternative is to build a new one. The proposed well would have to be at least 90 feet deep, and possible 100 ft., and 4 feet square. I have included the amount of $200.00 in the requisition to cover the cost of labour in digging and cribbing this well. If a well digging machine was employed it might be a little cheaper to dig the well but it would only be 30" square and so it would be impossible to clean it out when required or to dig further down when it dried up. The most satisfactory job is accomplished by digging the well by ordinary labour.

There is no water supply at this school at the present time so that it is imperative that this well be completed as soon as possible.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis, Indian Agent.

OTTAWA 9th November 1895

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo relative to the closing of the Montreal Lake School, and stating that Departmental letter of the 23rd ultimo was the first intimation you had of the intention to close this school. In reply I beg to refer you to official letter of the 3rd April 1894 enclosing a copy of a Memo submitted by His Lordship the Bishop of Saskatchewan and Calgary in person, setting forth the requirements of his Diocese for the carrying on of the Boarding Schools therein together with a copy of my answer thereto, and informing you that the amount necessary to provide for 10 girls authorized to be taken at Emmanuel College was to come out of the appropriation for Montreal Lake School which was to be closed. The ten girls above referred to have been admitted to Emmanuel College, and it was to give effect to this agreement that notice was to be given for the closing of the Church of England School at Montreal Lake. As, however, the proposed arrangement does not appear to have been clearly understood, Mr Archdeacon Mackay will be written to by the Department on this subject, and pending his reply no further action need be taken by you in the matter.

Your obedient servant,

The Indian Commissioner,
Regina, N.W.T.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 113793 of the 9th inst., and in reply to inform you that I had not previously received any intimation of the intention of the Department to close the Day School at Montcalm Lake. With reference to the ten girls authorized to be taken at Emmanuel College, it was simply stated in the Memorandum copy-fact furnished to the Bishop of Saskatchewan from your office, dated 2nd April 1894—

"As regards Emmanuel College, 10 girls may be taken, provided the Church Authorities are willing to accept a per Capita grant of $60 per annum from 1st July '94."

I am afraid there is very little likelihood at present of any of the children from Montcalm Lake being sent.

The Deputy Chief Superintendent of Indian Affairs

Ottawa
Lake being sent to the Battleford School. Later on, if that school becomes more popular among the Indians, as I trust it will be before long, there may be a better prospect, but I should think the full quota of pupils allowed for that institution might be furnished by the reserves in the neighborhood of Battleford. If I may be permitted to express an opinion, I would submit that the day schools in the neighborhood of such an institution as the Battleford School, should be the first closed before those in isolated places like Montreal Lake.

I had an interview with His Lordship Bishop Pinkham and Archdeacon Mackay last week and arranged that Rev. Thos. Clarke should be engaged as Teacher at Montreal Lake for nine months commencing from the 1st October next.

Sir,

There had been no attendance at the school since the school since the 25th February and as no little good is being done, owing to the fact that Indians stay but a short time of the year on the camping ground near the school, I think this school should be closed.

There are 10 boys & 9 girls on the roll, most of them in the first standard. The teacher does not like his work on the place and I think it is a great waste of money.

If the school is to be continued some repairs should be made to the roof but as the building is used as a church and as the teacher...
Teachers and Indians have so little work to do, it would show a little enterprise on their part and the Department would be encouraged to continue the grant.

Montreal Lake Reserve

Sir - We just got word from the Bishop of Sask. telling us that the Indian Department is going to close our School (Dec. 31). Since the undersigned are writing to say that we don't wish the Department to take such action. Mr. Settee our present teacher is doing well enough considering the amount of work he has to do every day. Under present conditions the Department should consider that it is not so easy to find a man that can do any better than Mr. Settee. To tell you the truth, Mr. Settee is doing good work, and all the Indians like him. He can speak both languages and that is the kind of man we like to have in our midst. Of course we don't mean to tell you that the children are have a first class qualification, and the reason is that it is impossible for the Indians to keep their families on the reserve. They have to leave for hunting grounds and take their children away. The only way it could be done to get satisfaction is to have a place of residence for the pupils where they could be by their parents to attend School. So we request the Department to change their plans and not to close the School. It is not right for any Department to take such action and to put Mr. Settee in such a position this time of year after him being so faithful to the work for so many years.

Signed: William Bird

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

J. R. Settee, teacher of the Montreal Lake School in the Carlton Agency, applies for an increase in his salary.

Mr. Settee is a half-breed, 39 years of age, and is married. At the time of his appointment he received a salary of $300.00 per year, which was increased to $400.00, his present salary, on July 1st, 1913. Besides the salary he has also received the bonus at the rate of $150.00 per annum and is allowed $60.00 a year as dispenser of medicines and rations. He states that he is also in receipt of $75.00 per annum from the Anglican Church for missionary work. He has no professional qualifications.

It was the intention to close this school in 1918, but, at the request of the Bishop of Saskatchewan and also on receipt of a petition from the Indians, the school was kept open and the services of Mr. Settee retained. There is an enrolment of 25 pupils, with an average attendance of 16.

The Bishop states that, while he is not very successful as a teacher, still he is faithful and satisfactory to the Indians.

There is no doubt that a salary of $400.00 is very small, and, as the Department has retained him so long in the service, I consider that he should be granted an increase, in view of the fact that he has only received one increase in twenty years' service and is a married man with a family. I would recommend that he be allowed $100.00, if he is continued on as teacher. The Bishop states that it would be difficult to obtain the services of another man for this school who would be as satisfactory to the Indians.

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 107-6-1 of the 1st inst., asking for a report on the work being performed by Mr. Settee of the Montreal Lake Day School.

This is a difficult school to handle, on account of none of the Indians farming, all depending upon hunting and trapping for their livelihood, which means than when the parents leave in the Spring and Fall they take all the children with them, as they have not the means to leave them behind. When paying treaty this year, the Band took up the question of having the school close April and October of each year, instead of July and August, if the Department approves of this step, I think it will help the attendance.

If it is possible to get another teacher, I would recommend same, Mr. Settee has been at Montreal Lake for about 20 years; he has done good work in the past, and no doubt if he were moved to a new field, he would continue to do so, though I consider a change would be better for all concerned if at all possible. Being practically an Indian himself, he cannot now commend the respect that he should for the position he is holding.

If the Department consider putting in a new man, I would suggest that a man be at Montreal Lake before any change is made, as it is essential that one be at that point to look after the rations etc., on account of the very bad roads during the summer it is impossible for me to make frequent trips.

I have the honor to be,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

Very Reverend Sir:

Reports which have been received from the Indian Day School at Montreal Lake show that during the past school year this school was in operation only 143 days out of a total number of 200 teaching days required in the year. The reason appears to have been that the Indians and their families were absent from the reserve.

Mr. Settee, the Teacher, has been at Montreal Lake for about 20 years. He has, no doubt, done good work in the past; but it is now considered that a change of teachers at this school would be better for all concerned as, from reports received, he is not now commending the respect from the Indians that he should, for the position he is holding. Our agent suggests that, if the Department considers putting in a new man to take charge, the person appointed should be at Montreal Lake before any change is made, as it is essential that someone be at that point to look after the rations, etc.

In view of Mr. Settee's long and faithful services, the Department does not desire to deal hastily in dispensing with his services, and I shall be pleased to have your views as to whether it would not be advisable to make a change in the teacher at this point. It may be that Mr. Settee's services could be used elsewhere and that the change would be beneficial, both in the interests of the school work at Montreal Lake and to Mr. Settee himself.

The agent considers that there would be a more regular attendance if this school was closed during April and October of each year, instead of July and August, as at present, as the Indians would not then be absent for their spring and fall hunts.

You are, no doubt, fully aware of the situation at Montreal Lake, and I would be pleased to have your opinion regarding the making of a change of teacher at this school, also whether you consider that a change should be made in the time the annual holidays are taken.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Miss Bashford of the Anglican Teachers' Hostel very kindly wrote to tell me that you could possibly find use for me as a teacher and worker at Montreal Lake. I belong to the Fellowship of the Maple Leaf, and I think you would find me an enthusiastic and willing worker.

I don't believe the simple life would damp me, because I warn you that I am fond of music and have in my truck a violin—I hope to learn to play it some day. My other qualifications are as follows:

First Class Academic standing
15 weeks' Normal Training
Speak, read and write French and German

P.T.O.
First Aid Certificate (St. John's Ambulance)
6 months' experience in Sunday School teaching.

Deputy Superintendent General.
Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 107-6-1 of the 7th inst. wherein you ask for a report on Mrs. Pereira, Assistant Field Matron at the Montreal Lake Reserve, who recently made application for an increase in salary.

When I visited Montreal Lake reserve early during the month of December, there were thirty-five children attending the day school. The meals which are prepared by Mrs. Pereira are made up of supplies as furnished by the department, such as flour, biscuits, bacon, tea and rice; no vegetables are on hand on account of the late teacher Mr. Settee not growing any, and which cannot be procured in the district.

In addition to Mrs. Pereira preparing meals, she also looks after the sick on the reserve, and gives particular attention to the welfare of the school children. There is no comparison between the work she is doing and that of which Mrs. Settee did, all that Mrs. Settee did was to prepare the noon day meal when the school was open, and as far as I know she never attended to the ailing.

Regarding Mrs. Pereira's statement that the children are backward and afflicted with sores, I would mention that this is her first experience in Indian work, and no doubt she finds conditions very different from what she has been used to in the white settlements. Every year I have had Dr. J.D. Duncan, of Leask, visit this reserve, and he has always found conditions very satisfactory, that is with the exception of minor ailments which all are subject to, conditions as I find them on Montreal Lake reserve compare very favourably with other reserves of this Agency.

I have to visit Montreal Lake reserve during the early part of February, when I will take particular note of the condition of the children and again write you on my return, as I am fully convinced that conditions are not as serious as Mrs. Pereira would give the impression.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

I beg to submit the following report in connection with the Day Schools included in the Carlton Agency. There are seven Day Schools altogether, namely, Montreal Lake, Little Red River, Sturgeon Lake, Wahpaton Sioux, Big River, Sandy Lake, and Mistawasis. I visited all these schools, but with the exception of the Montreal Lake School they were not in operation. I accompanied the Agent when he was making his annuity payments, and the children had been given a holiday for the occasion. I, however, made inquiry into the conditions pertaining to each school, when on the different reserves.

MONTREAL LAKE DAY SCHOOL.

I visited this school on June 24th., and found 14 boys and 7 girls present, out of an enrolment of 27. The average attendance for the quarter was about 58% of the enrolment. The teacher complains that the parents take away their children when they go off hunting and trapping. It will be hard to prevent this condition, owing to the fact that the Indians depend upon hunting, trapping and fishing solely, as a means of livelihood, and this

I can find very little evidence of his having taught the people anything, inasmuch as none of the younger men and women who attended his school can speak English. Conditions have been better during the last five years, but really satisfactory results cannot be expected with such an intermittent attendance.

The school is built of logs, and is 21 x 32, with a 13 ft. ceiling. The walls and wainscoting inside are whitewashed, and are fairly clean. The shingles on the roof are tin and are leaking badly and should be replaced.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I beg to enclose herewith a report by Mr. Inspector Murison dealing with the various schools in the Carlton Agency.

Unfortunately the schools were closed for summer vacation at the time of the Inspector's visit, with the exception of Montreal Lake School. At this point out of an enrolment of 27 children he found an attendance of 21. The average attendance for the quarter was poor, being only 59%. You will note that the teacher complains the parents take the children away during hunting. It would be impossible for them to do otherwise. These Indians depend entirely on hunting as a means of earning a livelihood and they could not leave the children at home when they go off on hunting trips. It would appear that there is a good recruiting field here for a boarding school. This school has not been very outstanding, and how could it be otherwise, having a man of the type and ability of Robert Settee as teacher for such a long period. You will note that the young men and women who were at school during his regime cannot speak English, so that this type of school and teacher does not bring results to the department. The mid-day meal at this school is not a very substantial one.

At the Little Red River Day School the average attendance is 12.35, which is poor.

At the Sturgeon Lake Day School the average attendance is poor, being only 10%. Here also is a point where we might recruit for a boarding school.

The Round Plain Day School is a very small institution, the average attendance being 3.7%.

The Big River Day School was visited twice

Where he has fallen down is in carelessness in connection with his personal appearance and untidiness in his home and school premises. His Lordship appears quite anxious that the Department will consent to the transfer of Mr. Lowe to Red Earth to replace Mr. Plunkett. Dear Sir,

On my recent visit to Montreal Lake Reserve No. 106 on the 23rd. instant, I arrived via plane at 9.50 a.m. and went direct to Day School which I found in a dirty and hopeless condition.

Door of school was unlocked and no school was being held. Later I met Mr. Plunkett on the road dressed in overalls and he looked more like a labourer than a school teacher. He informed me that he had loaned the school for a dance the previous night and it was not his intention to hold school on the 23rd. A number of the seats were broken when I inspected the toilets I found them full of snow in a very dirty condition and children had been using play ground as a lavatory. Gates were down and things were just being let go to pieces.

On inspecting house he vacated a few months ago I found in one of the rooms a quantity of department drugs and supplies thrown all over the floor amongst rubbish. Some of the drugs were frozen and bottles broken.

On my last visit in January I had supplies sent in for a mid-day meal, but Mr. Plunkett did not bother to see that children got the meal. On my previous visits I could see that this man was slipping and asked him to fix up different things but nothing has been done.

Ottawa, May 13, 1937.

Venerable Sir:

I desire to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 4th instant and to state, by way of comment, that I have studied very carefully the statements you made in respect to conditions confronting Mr. Plunkett when he took charge of the Indian Day School at Montreal Lake.

I am enclosing, for your information, copy of a report sent forward to the Inspector of Indian Agencies for the province of Saskatchewan by Indian Agent R. S. Davis.

In view of the statements contained in Mr. Davis' report, it is exceedingly difficult for the Department to reconsider this case with the object of having Mr. Plunkett remain at his present school. It is just possible, of course, that the conditions to which you refer contributed to the present very unsatisfactory situation. In view of this fact, I have been wondering if it would be possible for you to discuss the matter with Mr. Davis and come to an arrangement whereby Mr. Plunkett might be transferred to another school. If this were done, it would have to be on the understanding that Mr. Plunkett's work would be reviewed at the end of a year, and, if found unsatisfactory, his services would be dispensed with.

Yours very sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Encl.

Venerable Archdeacon W.E.J. Paul,
Synod Office,
Prince Albert, Sask.
Ottawa, May 13, 1937.

Dear Sir:

On April 19th, last, we wrote to Venerable Archdeacon W. E. J. Paul, of Prince Albert, intimating that he should inform Mr. Plunkett that his services would not be required at the Montreal Lake Indian Day School after the end of the current academic year. We are now in receipt of a letter from Archdeacon Paul, in which he claims that the conditions confronting Mr. Plunkett when he began his duties at Montreal Lake, such as housing accommodation, distance from school, illness of his wife, etc., have temporarily discouraged him and are responsible for the existing conditions.

In our reply, we have pointed out to Archdeacon Paul that, in view of the statements contained in your report of March 29th, addressed to Dr. Thomas Robertson, it would be impossible for us to permit Mr. Plunkett to continue in charge of this school. We did suggest, however, that he might, by discussing the matter with you, arrange to have Mr. Plunkett transferred to another school, on the understanding that his work would be carefully reviewed at the end of a year, and, if found unsatisfactory, his services would be dispensed with.

We shall appreciate it very much if you can find it convenient to discuss the matter with Archdeacon Paul at your convenience.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.

December 6th 1935.

Mrs. Stenhouse is a capable and experienced teacher of sterling character. She would be an influence of great value in any school. She is intensely interested in her work and the children under her care. She has a competent grasp of subject matter and of teaching methods. Dear Sir:

We enclose herewith an application received by Rev. W. E. J. Paul from Mr. Stenhouse for the position of teacher in the Montreal Lake Indian Day School, made vacant by the dismissal of Mr. Flunkett.

We interviewed all applicants for the position and picked Mr. Stenhouse and his wife as the most likely looking couple. You will note from the application, that both have good teaching experience and good recommendations. Mrs. Stenhouse agrees to teach when Mr. Stenhouse is busy with outside duties. They appear to be a bright and well educated couple and are much interested in school work. We are of the opinion that they would be quite suitable for the position in question.

We would recommend that Mr. Stenhouse be given this position on a years trial and if found suitable a more permanent appointment could be made. This man should be notified as soon as possible as there is no one at this point at the present time, Mr. Flunkett having left. We trust that you will see fit to appoint this couple as outlined above.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Yours truly,

FORM 14
Ottawa, July 19th, 1926.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 12th instant, enclosing copy of a communication from Mr. F. J. Pereira, teacher of the Montreal Lake Indian Day School, in which he requests permission to open the school during the month of August, as all the children are on the Reserve, and close the school during the month of December, next, when the children are away with their parents for the hunting season.

In reply I beg to say that, in view of your recommendation, the Department will approve of the teacher conducting this school during the month of August and closing same during the month of December, next. This arrangement is for the next school year only, and, should it be found successful, a request should again be made for any further continuance of this change in the holiday period. It is presumed that the school is closed during the present month.

Please inform Mr. Pereira of the permission granted to teach during August, next, and to close the school during the month of December.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

John Weir, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Leask, Sask.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Ottawa, March 25th, 1935.

Sir:

I desire to inform you that the Department has decided to transfer Rev. J. L. Lowe, teacher of the Montreal Lake Indian Day School, to the Red Earth Indian Day School in the Pas Agency.

Reverend Mr. Lowe will be succeeded at Montreal Lake by Mr. B. T. Flunkett, who has been teaching at the Red Earth Indian Day School.

These transfers will be effective from September 1st, 1935.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

R. S. Davis, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Lanska, Sask.

Dear Sir:

We received a letter today from Robert Campbell, teacher at the Indian School at Montreal Lake. He stated that he had forwarded a letter to us a few days previous and had enclosed a check for $95.00, his salary for the month of September, this we were to deposit to his account. Up to date the letter has not arrived. I wrote to the Bank of Montreal at Prince Albert, with whom he intends to deal, explaining the situation. I also spoke to the Post Office authorities, and they are trying to trace it. We would be pleased if you would do everything possible to stop payment on the check, by any person other than Mr. Campbell.

Owing to the poor mail service, and no telephone service, we are unable to communicate with Mr. Campbell, and are at a loss to know what to do.

Thanking you, I am

(Yours truly,
(Mrs.) S. Campbell)
Ottawa,
October 13, 1939.

Dear Madam:

With reference to your letter of the 6th instant our records show that cheque 13251 for $95.00 in payment of the September salary of Mr. Robert Campbell, teacher of the Montreal Lake Indian day school, was forwarded from here on September 30.

The cheque has not yet been cashed. You should continue your endeavours to locate it and if it is not found you should advise me later.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mrs. S. Campbell,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter 107-6-5 dated Mar. 18th, I am returning herewith Voucher No.951 with the necessary corrections made.

The error in regard to Alex Chip was made by the foreman; This was an Indian from Yellow Knife, who had been in Prince Albert jail; They could not return him to his home after he served his sentence, owing to flying conditions; I took him to Montreal Lake and gave him rations, and he was put to work on the School building, he worked steady, but we only paid him enough for Tobacco and incidentals, as he was not experienced, and was not very valuable to us; This is why the foreman had him down for 15 hours and paid him 30 cents; I have corrected this to 2 hours at 15 cents.

In forwarding this voucher only the totals were checked, as we were very busy at the time; The error is regretted,

Dear Sir:

Build a chimney at a total cost of $50.00: The one now in use is not properly located for the kitchen stove and is unsafe.

OTTAWA, Ont.

ATTENTION/Mr. Philep Phelan-
Chief Training Division:

Dear Sir:-

RE: Montreal Lake School Account:

A year ago last November we had the pleasure of supplying the above school with considerable building material through your Indian Agent, Mr. R. S. Davis, of Leask Sask.

To date, however, we have not been paid for this material, and have had considerable correspondence with your Agent, Mr. Davis, and last July 19th, he forwarded a copy of a letter sent by yourself to him, explaining that the delay was due to the fact that the Appropriation funds had not come through to your Department, but that you were expecting this to happen shortly and that our account would then receive immediate attention.

Considerable time, however, has now again elapsed and we would very much appreciate a cheque from your office. This material was sold on such a close margin that interest on this money has now more than depleted any possible profit that might have accrued to us for handling.

Kindly give this the immediate attention that it deserves.

Yours very truly,

NORTH STAR LUMBER COMPANY, LIMITED

AGM: KS

GENERAL MANAGER

The North Star Lumber Company Ltd.,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter No.107-6-6 dated February the 18th, regarding the Montreal Lake School.

Montreal Lake Indian Day School was erected in the early Winter of 1939, and is of log construction on a cement foundation, the logs are chinked inside and out, and lined inside with wall board; The class room is about 28 ft. square, and is lined with plaster board, and the walls are 9½ ft. high, cloak rooms are at one end and on the other end is the kitchen for the mid-day meals, and a room where a large furnace could be installed, but at present is heated with a stove from the old school which is cased in with galvanized iron, and which is too small for a class room of this size, unless the fire is kept on steady night and day; One must remember that the last fire put on in the school in this western country where a fireman or a caretaker is not supplied, is at about four o'clock in the afternoon; As the first fire in the morning is about eight, and no fire on Saturday or Sunday, any building of this size in below zero weather, will take all day to get it heated up, unless a large heat unit is installed; This building has now been up since 1939, and the plaster should be gone over as is the case with all log buildings; The ceiling was not insulated at the time, owing to the cost of bringing in this material such a long distance, but now a planning mill is close to this point, and the ceiling could be insulated for $20.00,
Dear Sir:-

With further reference to my letter 913-7-31 today date, re Montreal Lake Shcool,
I forgot to mention that the nearest water is the lake, which is one-quarter of a mile away;
I have had the Indians dig two different wells, but was unable to get water, though one well
was 40 ft. deep; The digging is very hard owing to the formation being fairly rocky,
water can be secured in shallow wells, but it is unfit for use, this being just drainage
from the muskegs; If a man was employed as stated in my previous letter, he could haul the
water from the lake.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.
R.S.Davis.

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of July 3, 1941, with respect to Mr. Robert Balfour Campbell, I have to advise you that Mr. Campbell was employed in the Training Division of the Welfare and Training Service, Indian Affairs Branch, as Teacher at the Montreal Lake Indian Day School, Carlton Agency, Saskatchewan, from September 1, 1939, to May 23, 1940, inclusive, at a salary of $95.00 per month.

Yours very truly,

Chief Executive Assistant.

J. Anderson, Esq.,
Office of the Comptroller of the Treasury,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
Dear Sir:

I wish to refer you to Departmental letter No. 107-6-1 of February 20th last, regarding the teacher's residence and school at Montreal Lake. I also wish to refer to my letters of last Winter which Mr. Waite, the School teacher, wrote to me, copies of which I forwarded to the Branch.

I now wish to state that I visited Montreal Lake on the 12th ultimo in company with Mr. R.S. Davis, the Indian Agent, and as we stayed overnight at Waskesiu, we were at the Reserve between 9.00 and 10.00 o'clock in the morning, and stayed there until 10.00 o'clock in the evening.

I am sure you will wonder why the School was built where it is, allegedly one half mile from the teacher's residence. I am drawing a sketch showing where the teacher's residence is and also the highway and the school. I stepped this distance between the school and the teacher's residence and found that it was 1000 ft., in other words, less than one fifth of a mile. The reason the school was built on its present site was that it had to be this distance to keep the children away from the road, as there is a gravelled highway running past the teacher's residence as far as the Hudson's Bay store, which is one mile north from the teacher's residence.

Regarding the heating of the school, I am sure you will realize that up in a place like Montreal Lake, which is quite a large body of water, the weather becomes pretty cold in the Winter time and the furnace that heats the school is not large enough to heat it during the extreme cold weather. Also, the furnace was made out of a box stove. To remedy this a large stove should be placed right in the school, such as the Lumberman's Heater, which has a flat shelf on top of the stove where the mid-day meal could be kept warm. It would only be necessary for the teacher to keep this stove going during the cold weather.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ont.

The teacher's residence.......
The teacher's residence is also very cold and storm windows are required. You cannot expect a house in that part of the country to be habitable without storm windows. Also, the window frames need caulking with oakum and a fine wire nailed over the frame for about a foot from the frame on to the logs and then plastered. If this is done I can see no reason why the house will not be warm.

A 25 barrel tank for soft water is also required as the teacher has to carry the water from the lake, a distance of about a mile. I understand that it is impossible to get a satisfactory well, or at least this is what I was told. The teacher also has a garage that needs repairing. Mr. Waite has a car and I deem it absolutely necessary to fix this garage up and have a stove put in it. I believe Mr. Davis said that he could furnish a small stove for this purpose. Mr. Waite is a long distance from Prince Albert and the Park is closed up in the winter time, but the highway is kept open. You will realize how necessary it is for him to keep his car running in the winter time so that it will start at a moment's notice in case of sickness and so forth. To repair the garage would cost about $40.00. To make the necessary repairs to the house, such as fitting the window frames with storm windows, etc., it will be necessary to have Mr. Davis bring in a carpenter from Prince Albert as there are no Indians capable of doing this work at Montreal Lake. The storm windows can be purchased from Prince Albert from an approved source, and fitted by the carpenter.

I would therefore, suggest that Mr. Davis be given the necessary authority to buy all material required and hire a carpenter to do the above mentioned work. He should also be given authority to make arrangements for a soft water tank and the repairing of the garage, and be authorized to purchase the necessary stove for the school, and stove pipes. If these repairs are brought about I am sure that Mr. Waite's difficulties will be over and he will be able to live comfortably in the winter. These people have been with us for quite a number of years and they have always done their work well, helping us out in every way possible, not only in the school but with outside work on the reserve, and they are still doing this work for us.

In conclusion I might bring to your attention that Mr. Waite gives out the rations to the Indians and more or less acts as an Overseer for Mr. Davis, as well as looking after a school garden, which will necessitate his staying there for most of the holiday. Still he is only paid a school teacher's salary.

The question of holidays was discussed with me while I was there and as the Indians are away in November and December, often taking their children with them, and the same applies in April, we all thought that probably it would be better to have, say two months' holidays during the winter and only one month during the summer. I advised both Mr. Davis and Mr. Waite that I did not think the Branch would have any objection to the teacher taking the two months during the winter and one month during the summer as long as the school is only taught nine months of the year.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

I wish to inform you that last week I visited Montreal Lake and while there I had a talk with Mr. Waite, teacher of the day school on that reserve.

The only thing Reverend Waite required for the school was six packages of Kalsomine and I told him to buy this because I thought you would not mind my taking this authority on myself since it does not amount to very much.

As you will probably recall, I obtained authority to have some repairs done on the teacher's house here a year ago last Summer and Reverend Waite informs me the house is much better now. However, in spite of this last Winter they had to close up the front of the house because the weather was so terribly cold with temperatures as low as 60 degrees below zero. The only thing we can do to improve matters now is to put a box stove in the front room. There is a stove pipe hole in the fireplace.

I do not know where we are going to get a box stove but if you will give me the authority to buy one together with eight pipes, one elbow pipe, and a stove board I shall endeavour to secure one.

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.
Ottawa,
August 3, 1943.

Ottawa, October 21, 1936.

Memorandum:

With reference to the building of a teacher's residence, Montreal Lake School, on looking over the file it would appear that both a new school and residence is required.

Funds were provided only for a residence. Will you please advise me if a residence only is contemplated, and if the same will be located on the site of the present school or on property owned by the Department.

Architect for the Department.
October 26, 1936.

MEMORANDUM:

MR. O. R. R.,-

Replying to your memo of the 21st instant, with reference to the building of a teacher's residence at the Montreal Lake Indian Day School, I would suggest, as it is now late in the season, that this work be not proceeded with.

The local Indian Agent and the former Inspector - Mr. Murison - also the Anglican Church authorities now request that a new day school building be also provided. I am including an item in the Estimates for the coming fiscal year to erect a combined school and teacher's residence, and, if the amount is allowed, the work could be proceeded with next summer.

Dear Sir:

Re: Mid-day Meals, Day Schools.

Owing to the fact that I consider these meals absolutely necessary, not only in the interests of the health of the children, but also for the purpose of securing attendance, I have strongly advocated their necessity. I now find, however, that some of our teachers are asking for a considerable increase in their allowance.

We have in Saskatchewan Mr. Kerley, clerk, Pelly Agency, who prior to taking that position spent 12 years teaching in one of our schools; also Mr. Goodman, teacher on Sandy Lake, has many years' experience. From my own personal knowledge, I know that these two teachers have always supplied good nourishing meals, many times paying for them out of their own pockets. I have therefore asked them to submit what, in their opinion, should be sufficient to supply a good nourishing meal, not taking into consideration vegetables, which in my opinion should be grown in a school garden, or where this is impossible, supplied from the Community farm.

I am now in receipt of their replies, which I am enclosing. You will note that there is very little difference in their estimates. I am attaching also a form which Mr. Kerley states was formerly used and should be used again.

I would recommend that the Department, from this information, adopt a fixed amount per pupil for each school, and thus get away from leaving the matter to the will of the teacher.

It might be noted that at some schools it is practically impossible to secure beef, and they have to use bacon instead. This would of course increase the cost a little.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

I desire to refer to your letter of September 19 with reference to midday meal supplies for the schools in the Carlton Agency. There appears to be a tendency to endeavour to turn our day schools into semi-residential schools. It was never the intention to supply what might be considered a full meal at midday at the day schools. Day schools are not equipped for this purpose and besides it would involve either a great deal of extra work on the older pupils or it would require the employment of someone to prepare the midday meal and present regulations do not permit our expending funds for the latter purpose.

The lunch at midday at day schools while nutritious should be as simple as possible. We appreciate the suggestions offered by Mr. Kerley and Mr. Goodman.

Very careful consideration has been given to the requests from the schools in the Carlton Agency and it is considered that only a light lunch should be served. With this in mind we are writing to Indian Agent Davis regarding the amount he can expend at each school.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

A recent report received from the Public School Inspector regarding his inspection of the Montreal Lake Indian day school refers to the poor condition of this building. This is a matter about which you have reported on previous occasions.

Would it be possible to construct a new school in a manner similar to that followed in the construction of the teacher's residence at Montreal Lake during the past summer? Please let me know if one or two class rooms would be necessary and, if so, you might comment on which of the under-mentioned kind of building could be erected most reasonably.

1. One class room (or two class rooms) with basement underneath for vocational purposes.

2. One class room (or two class rooms) without a basement and a separate small building erected for vocational purposes.

Whichever you recommend you should let me know if the Indians would do the necessary work provided food was supplied. At the same time you should advise as fully as possible the quantities of lumber, hardware etc. that would be necessary in order that we may have all the information required for our Purchasing Agent.

It is quite possible that we can provide the funds to purchase the materials before the end of March and the building could be erected next summer. If it is

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of December 14th, file 107-6-5, in regard to the building of a school at the Montreal Lake Reserve, a one class school room about 36 x 30 with a basement for vocational training is all that would be required.

The country is very marshy and so it would be advisable to dig a basement about four feet deep and then run the logs up about five feet to the main floor.

The Indians will do the necessary work under a foreman, the same as last year. The logs for the building would cost in the neighborhood of $100.00. I believe that it would be better if we would purchase about 40 bags of flour, the price being about $2.50 at Montreal Lake and pay them in kind. They could also get out some logs to saw for lumber for the rough work, such as rough inch lumber, 2nd dimensions. The sawing of this would cost us about $5.00 a thousand.

I have been very busy and have not had time to complete the estimate on the building but will forward same in the near future. Roughly, I would estimate that the building will cost about $1700.00 including a heating system.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

On page 8 of our estimates for 1939-40 we inserted four items totaling $456.50 for repairing the fences and school of this Agency. One item is for the amount of $300.00 for stuccoing the outside of the teacher's residence at Montreal Lake. This will not be necessary this year but, as I neglected to insert any amount for repairing and decorating the schools and residences, this amount could be used to advantage for this work.

I would appreciate knowing the amount that will be allowed for this Agency for repairs to the schools and teacher's residences so that I could distribute the amount properly. The Sturgeon Lake School and residence is in need of a lot of repairs. Little Red River School also is in need of some repairs inside the school. The fences at Sturgeon Lake, Little Red River and Ahtahkakoops Schools all need repairing. The amount asked for in the estimates, $456.50, should cover the necessary expenditures.

Dear Sir:

Under Purchase Order No. 9948, issued last February, 40 sacks of flour were purchased for the Indians of the Montreal Lake Reserve No. 106 to get out logs for the building of a new Day School on the Reserve this summer. No further word has been received in regard to the erection of this school.

The present school is unfit for use this winter. I am enclosing a requisition covering the materials that will be required to erect a building that would be suitable for use as a school this winter. The building could be completed next year when funds become available. You will notice in the requisition that the dimension lumber can be purchased at the Montreal Lake Reserve. At the present time there is a mill operating in the vicinity and this rough lumber could be purchased from them at a very considerable saving; the freight to the Reserve from Prince Albert would be saved and the price would be much cheaper. The cost of this lumber would be about $15.00 per M at the Reserve.

The labour required for this school would cost about $600.00. The Indians of the Montreal Lake Reserve could do most of the work but it might be necessary to hire a good carpenter for a few days. I could send one or two Indian carpenters from another Reserve for this purpose. If the erection of this building is authorized I would appreciate receiving an accountable cheque for the amount of the labour so that work could begin as soon as the materials are purchased. We have the logs for the walls already, as stated above, and the Indians could begin building these walls.

An early reply would be appreciated so that this school could be built before the cold weather sets in.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis, Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

AIR MAIL

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 26th instant with reference to the erection of a school on the Montreal Lake Reserve.

You may arrange for immediate purchase of the items shown on the attached requisition. It is noted from your letter that the rough lumber can be secured at a cost of approximately $15.00 a thousand. The other items on the requisition should be purchased from firms on the approved list.

An accountable cheque for $600.00 for labour will go forward under separate cover. Indian labour should be employed as far as possible. Quite recently you were informed regarding the person to consult if any white labour is necessary.

It appears from the second paragraph of your letter that even though the items shown on the attached requisition are supplied it will not complete the building. If an additional expenditure of two or three hundred dollars would complete it this fall I believe it would be advisable for you to do so. It is understood, of course, that every effort will be made to keep the cost as low as possible.

Yours truly,

R. S. Davis, Esq.,

Montreal Lake— I beg most earnestly for a residence for the teacher at Montreal Lake, J.R. Settee, who has been teaching faithfully for fourteen years at Moose Lake and at Montreal Lake, is living in a log house belonging to the Church, twenty-four years old and now unfit for use. The I.D. has never had any expense here for the teacher's residence. He is not a brilliant teacher, but he plods along faithfully, working under considerable difficulties. I think the I.D. ought to have a teacher's house there. The Indians there promised to get out the logs and to square them as their gift. Mr. Gunville, a trader there, will take the contract for building and haul out his own lumber for it. As the Indians are about to build a church there, much of which they will have to do themselves, I think it is very good of them to offer to give the logs for the teacher's house.

J. A. Newnham,
Bishop of Saskatchewan.
Ottawa, July 11, 1914.

Sir,

The Bishop of Saskatchewan reports that the house occupied by J. R. Settee, teacher of the Montreal Lake School, which belongs to the church, is now unfit for use and His Lordship states that the Indians have promised to get out logs for a new house and to square them. His Lordship asks the Department to furnish the material necessary to complete the house.

The Department would like to have a report from you as to whether you consider it necessary that a new house should be built and, if so, what would be the probable cost of the labour and material required. The Department would like you to enclose a rough sketch of the building it is proposed to put up.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 11th., ultimo, No.118793/5, re the house occupied by Mr. J.R. Settee, teacher of the Montreal Lake school. I have the honor to report that I found that his Lordship, the Bishop of Saskatchewan was perfectly right when he reported that the house in question was unfit for habitation.

Dear Sir:

With regard to your letter of Jan. 28th., file 107-6-8, in connection with the Teacher's residence at Montreal Lake, the house we are renting from the Hudson's Bay Co. is an old building of log construction. The logs are sitting on the ground and are rotted.

This building has very poor floors. It is very cold in winter, and not fit to spend any money on it to repair it, if it had been the Hudson's Bay Co. would have used it and repaired same last year instead of building a new home for their employee.

This Reserve is practically on the edge of the National Park and now has a highway as far as the Reserve and will be visited by many tourists and I feel that if at all possible something should be done to provide decent living quarters for the Teacher, and also build some Indian homes and clean this Reserve up. This report is considerably different from that contained in your letter of November 5, 1936, the last paragraph of which read "I would recommend leasing said building as it will save us building and settle house question for some time". Our difficulty in administering schools is increased when such divergent reports are received within a comparatively short space of time.

As you were informed in official letter of January 28 no special provision has been made for the erection of a new teacher's residence at Montreal Lake during the fiscal year 1935-39. However, it is found that an amount of $100.00 can be made available for securing the logs for a new building. Please arrange with the Indians to bring out these logs before the end of March.

In the second last paragraph of your letter of the 12th instant you state that most of the work on a new teacher's residence could be done by the Indians. Is it your opinion that the Indians at Montreal Lake are competent to erect a teacher's residence? You might let me know the approximate cost of the doors, windows etc. that would be required. When forwarding this information you should give full details regarding the articles necessary and the quantities in order that we may have sufficient information.

Dear Sir:

With regard to your letter of February 23rd, file 107-6-8; I note your remarks in regard to my report on leasing the Hudson's Bay house for a residence for the Teacher; this building has served the purpose for two years at a very small rental.

I have recently returned from Montreal Lake and the Indians are busy getting out logs as suggested in your letter, and will have them completed before the end of the present month. I have advanced them food supplies, which will be paid out of the proceeds from the logs.

Most of the work on a teacher's residence, particularly the rough work, can be done by the Indians; but I would recommend that a carpenter be hired as a foreman while the work was being done. Any work that the Indians do on this building, I would recommend that they be paid by food and clothing.

A building 30 x 32 with an 8' verandah, one storey, cottage roof, would be large enough. Would it be possible to get the Engineering Branch to make a plan that would be suitable. The house should have two bedrooms, kitchen, and living room and a small bath room. The frame work will be of logs, using plaster board on the inside.

Requisitions for the material required are enclosed. I have estimated the amount needed without a plan and adjustments may be made by the Engineering Branch.

Yours truly,

Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DEPUTY MINISTER

Re: Montreal Lake Indian Day School,
Province of Saskatchewan, Carlton
Indian Agency, Electoral District
of Prince Albert.

The teacher's residence at this school was built several years ago and became so dilapidated that it was necessary to rent a building from the Hudson's Bay Company. This building is also reported in bad condition at the present time.

This school and teacher's residence is on the main highway leading to Prince Albert National Park. Indian Agent Davis has urged the erection of a new teacher's residence. A suitable building can be erected under the supervision of Indian Agent Davis as the Indians will do the work free of charge. The material for the building will have to be supplied and this will cost approximately $713.00. Funds for the purpose are available in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1938-39.

The Indians are getting out logs to erect other buildings and it is therefore advisable to have the teacher's residence erected at the same time. I would appreciate receiving as soon as possible the approval of the Honourable the Minister to incur the expenditure mentioned above for the teacher's residence. I attach three requisitions for supplies. On each of these I am supplying the information given to me by the Indian Agent. In the event of the Honourable the Minister approving the expenditure I would appreciate if you would hand these requisitions to the Purchasing Agent.

Director.

Dear Sir:

I beg to submit my report on Montreal Lake Reserve Carlton Agency, which I visited on Wednesday June 1.

Government Buildings

Warehouse, a log building in very good condition. Teachers' residence and school. These buildings are the property of the church. The residence is unfit for habitation. The teacher is living in a rented building. The school is very old and altogether unsuitable for the purpose. A new school should be provided. The logs are out for the teachorage and they are now excavating for the basement. The funds at their disposal will not allow a full basement, it is my opinion that if possible sufficient funds should be allowed for a full basement otherwise it will be almost impossible to keep the house comfortable in that severe climate. Arrangements should be made to have the logs for a school taken out this winter and a school erected next summer. There are about 46 children at this school.

Thos. Robertson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies Saskatchewan.

It is very hard to estimate the exact amount of rations that will be required but I think the amount in the requisition should go a long way towards finishing this structure.

These supplies should be furnished as soon as possible, together with the shingles, lumber, sash and doors as included in our requisitions of March 16th. This work is now being held up pending the arrival of these supplies. The basement of the building is now completed and some of the logs are in place.

Memorandum:

PURCHASING AGENT:

I enclose requisition for rations, to be used by Indians working on the teacher's residence at Montreal Lake. Instead of paying wages in this case, we are issuing rations to them.

The supplies mentioned will be required at an early date in order not to delay the erection of the building. However, I am not exactly certain that the agent requested the proper quantities of the various articles. In order to save time, I would suggest that you obtain prices on the articles shown on the attached purchase requisition, and, in the meantime, I am communicating with the Indian agent to check the quantities. As soon as he replies, I shall advise you and the order can then be placed.

T. R. L. MacInnes,

July 27th 1938.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of July 19th, file 107-6-8, in regard to our requisition for rations to be issued to the Indians while building the Teacher's Residence at the Montreal Lake Reserve, I do not feel that this requisition was excessive.

The following work has already been done on the residence and rations issued to the Indians from goods I received for the building of the Indian dwellings:

4 men, digging basement, clearing timber, worked 2 weeks approximately at $1.50 per day $72.00
6 men putting up logs for walls, 10 days @ $1.50 per day 90.00
4 men putting in cement foundation 3 days @ $1.50 18.00

Total $180.00

These figures are only approximate as all the return of labour sheets are not yet received from Montreal Lake. Out of the requisition for supplies, as submitted, for the amount of $254.00, there is only a balance of $74.00, approximately, for putting on the roof, flooring, shingling, and plastering.

I consider that this is a reasonable figure as, if this work was done in any other way it would cost over twice as much.

Yours truly,

Dear Sir:

The Department finds it necessary to return the enclosed accounts in connection with the erection of a teacher's residence at the Montreal Lake Indian Day School. It will be necessary to attach to the account pay lists receipted by the Indians. These pay lists should show the number of days employed etc., and in signing the pay lists the Indians will acknowledge receipt of the supplies which have been purchased for their use.

I also find it necessary to return the account which you forwarded covering the cost of a furnace. No authority appears to have been given you to purchase this. In addition you are fully aware of present purchasing regulations. If the furnace was necessary you should have reported the matter to the Department and purchase would have been made by the Purchasing Branch.

With reference to your purchase order of August 20, copy of which is enclosed, you may purchase from firms on the approved list the articles mentioned at a cost not exceeding $47.40. Dear Reverend Waite:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st instant and I am very sorry to learn of the inconvenience you and Mrs. Waite are experiencing. Also I note that you have had a fire in your residence and the floor in the front room was damaged, making it impossible for you to use that room or the bedroom which joins it.

In reply I wish to say that you may take steps immediately to repair the floor. If the joists were burned under the fire place you may only be able to make a temporary job of the repairs but it will serve for the time being. I do not know how you get lumber at Montreal Lake but I suppose there is a sawmill or someone in that vicinity who handles lumber. However, as the quantity of lumber will not be great you may take steps to procure it and I presume someone in that neighbourhood will be able to help you bring about the repairs to make the house habitable.

When this repair work is completed you may send the bills here and I shall forward them to Ottawa. In the meantime I am sending a copy of your letter to our Branch so that they may learn of the conditions under which you people are living.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Indian Agencies.

Rev. G.J. Waite,
MONTREAL LAKE, Sask.
Montreal Lake, Sask.,
Jany 25/1941

M. Christianson Esq.,
Federal Building
Regina.

Dear Sir:

I thought I had better notify you that we have had a fire in the house. There is not a great deal of damage except to the floor in the front room. There is an open fire place and I believe that the floor joists run right under the fire place. I believe that they burnt through under the fire place and worked along under the floor. There is a bit of damage to the floor but there was no other damage. It means we cannot use that room or our bedroom which joins that room. The house is very cold because there are no storm windows. This week with the so called furnace, the cook stove and the open fire going, Mrs. Wait sat around in a fur coat. It is not very convenient now.

The school is heated with an overhead furnace. Mr. Davis thinks it works but to be candid it does not. This week the children sat in school in their hats, coats and mitts. The school fire is always alight by 8 o'clock in the morning and yet on Friday you could see the frost on the inside walls when I closed school in the afternoon.

I have put in 16 years service in the Department but this is hard place I have ever tackled. The school work is behind simply because the children have not been taught.

I have not notified Leask for I cannot seem to get an answer from them.

Yours truly,

(Signed) G. J. Waite.
Dear Sir:

I am herewith attaching a letter that I have just received from the Reverend G.J. Waite, teacher at Montreal Lake, which speaks for itself. I am also attaching copy of a letter that I have written to him authorizing him to go ahead with what repairs are necessary to the floor in the front room of the teacher's residence, which was damaged by fire. I trust this is in order.

It is regrettable that the Reverend and Mrs. Waite are living under conditions such as he describes, as they have rendered splendid work in the Indian Department in years past on the John Smith Reserve. I advised you some time ago that I intend to visit this Agency during the coming Spring.

Yours truly,

M. Christianson,
General Superintendent of Agencies.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 30th ultimo and approve the action which you have taken in authorizing Mr. Waite to repair a portion of the floor of the Montreal Lake teacher's residence which was damaged by fire. As you are no doubt aware a new teacher's residence was erected at Montreal Lake under the direction of Indian Agent Davis in the summer of 1938. This building cost $1253.27 of which amount $240.55 was for labour and the balance for material and hardware. As Mr. Davis was supposed to have personally supervised the construction of this building it is difficult to understand why Rev. Mr. Waite considers it so unsatisfactory. I note that you intend to visit the Carlton Agency during the coming spring and at that time you will no doubt go to Montreal Lake and you can then report to the Department regarding the teacher's residence and the school, both of which were built under the Agent's direction.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

I would ask you to kindly make the correction in these charges to the proper school; This error is much regretted; The account had not been marked Sturgeon Lake School by the plumbing company.

Yours truly,

Clerk in Charge.
T.B.Prince.
